explanations: The French phrase "un grand nombre de fois" (a great number of times) within the larger clause is simplified to "many times" in the English version, using more common and concise vocabulary.

The French temporal clause begins with "Dans le temps que" (In the time that/When). The English translation simplifies this initiating phrase by using "While," a more concise and common conjunction, which streamlines the overall sentence structure.

The French phrase "paroissent faire un tour" (appear to make a turn/circle), which describes the apparent motion, is simplified to the more direct and vivid "roll about." This uses a more common verb and avoids the somewhat periphrastic construction, making the image clearer and the language more accessible.

The concise French "Imagination pure" (Pure imagination) is expanded in the English translation to "Nothing else... but pure imagination." This expansion, while making the text segment longer, simplifies by reducing the original's density and making the assertion more explicit and emphatic, which can aid immediate comprehension.

The French subjunctive clause "que je vous parle" (that I speak to you) is simplified in the English translation to the more direct infinitive phrase "to tell you." This change reduces grammatical complexity by avoiding the subjunctive mood.

The French construction "la diverse maniere dont notre mouvement nous les fait rencontrer" (the diverse manner in which our movement makes us encounter them) features a relative clause with a causative verb. This is simplified in English to "the different manner of our meeting them in our motion," which uses a more concise nominalization (gerund phrase "our meeting them") and avoids the complex clausal structure.

The somewhat abstract French expression "que leur regularité coûtât moins à la Terre" (that their regularity cost less to the Earth) is simplified. The English translation "that their Regularity should be less troublesome to the Earth" clarifies the nature of this "cost" in more concrete and commonly understood terms ("less troublesome"), enhancing readability and accessibility of the concept.

The French phrase "on ne l'a guere ménagée" (one has hardly spared it / it has hardly been treated gently) involves an impersonal construction ("on") and the nuanced verb "ménager." The English translation simplifies this to the direct statement "She is not easily movable." This makes the idea more straightforward by replacing the nuanced, passive-leaning original with a statement about an inherent characteristic, reducing both lexical and structural complexity, albeit with a shift in nuance.

The French active impersonal construction "on luy demande bien de l'agilité" (one demands much agility from it) is simplified in the English translation. "it will require a good proportion of Agility" removes the explicit impersonal agent ("on") and shifts to describing an inherent requirement of the Earth. This simplifies the sentence structure by avoiding the active demand by an unspecified agent.

The French clause "il faudroit qu'il le fissent" (it would be necessary that they did it), which is an impersonal construction ("il faudroit que") combined with a subjunctive verb ("fissent"), is simplified. The English translation "so they must needs do" employs a more direct modal construction, removing the impersonal element and the subjunctive mood, thereby reducing grammatical complexity.

The French term "une grosse masse" (a large mass) is translated as "a great lump." The word "lump," being more informal and common in everyday language compared to "mass" (which can carry more technical or formal connotations), simplifies the vocabulary for a popular audience.

chunks.sourceHtml: P010: Oh! répliqua-t-elle, le Soleil & les Astres sont tout de feu, le mouvement ne leur coúte rien; mais la Terre ne paroît guere portative. Et croiriez-vous, repris-je, si vous n'en aviez point l'expérience, que ce fût quelque chose de bien portatif, qu'un gros Navire monté de cent cinquante pièces de Canon, chargé de plus de trois mille hommes, & d'une très grande nombre de Marchandises? Cependant il ne faut qu'un petit soufle de vent pour le faire aller sur l'eau, parce que l'eau est liquide, & que se laissant diviser avec facilité, elle résiste peu au mouvement du Navire. Ainsi la Terre, toute massive qu'elle est, est aisément portée dans la matiere celeste, qui est mille fois plus fluide que l'eau, & qui remplit tout ce grand espace où nagent les Planètes. Et où faudroit-il que la Terre fût cramponnée pour résister au mouvement de cette matière céleste, & ne pas s'y laisser emporter? C'est comme si une petite boule de bois pouvoit ne pas suivre le courant d'une Riviere.
chunks.manualHtml: P008: Oh, says she, the Sun and Stars consist of fire, their motion costs them little; but the Earth seems not easily manageable. And would you believe, said I, if you did not know it by experience, that a great Ship mounted with an hundred and fifty pieces of Artilery, man'd with above three thousand men, and well laden with Merchandise, would be a thing easily portative? in the mean time a little puff of Wind suffices to drive it upon the Water; because the Water being liquid, is easily divided, and makes no resistance to the motion of the Ship; so the Earth, though an unweildy mass, is easily carried through the celestial matter, which is ten thousand times more fluid than Water, and fills all that vast space where the Planets swim. And where is it necessary that the Earth should be riveted to resist the motion of that Celestial matter? 'Tis as if a little Boul of Wood could be able not to follow the Current of a River.

explanations: The French "ne...guere portative" (scarcely seems portable/manageable) uses the nuanced term "guere" (hardly, scarcely). The English translation "seems not easily manageable" simplifies this by using the more direct and less subtly shaded phrase "not easily." This makes the statement about the Earth's properties more straightforward.

The French sentence structure "que ce fût [description], [subject]" (that it were [description], [subject]) is a more complex, inverted presentational form. The English translation simplifies this by reorganizing it into a more standard and direct subordinate clause structure: "that [subject] would be [description]", which enhances readability by using a more common syntactic pattern.

The French reflexive participial phrase "se laissant diviser avec facilité" (literally "letting itself be divided with ease" or "being easily divisible by its nature") describes an inherent property with a degree of agency. The English translation simplifies this to a more direct and common passive voice construction "is easily divided," reducing syntactic complexity.

The French "elle résiste peu" (it offers little resistance) indicates a small amount of resistance. The English "makes no resistance" simplifies this by removing the concept of degree and presenting an absolute state (no resistance at all). This reduction of nuance simplifies the idea, potentially for stronger rhetorical effect or easier comprehension, at the cost of fidelity to the original measure.

The French phrase includes a second purpose expressed by the infinitive "& ne pas s'y laisser emporter?" (and not allow itself to be carried away by it?), which elaborates on the idea of resisting. The English translation omits this second descriptive part of the clause, thereby reducing the length and density of the sentence by removing this elaboration, making the statement more concise.

chunks.sourceHtml:
P011: Mais, répliqua-t-elle encore, comment la Terre avec tout son poids se soûtient- elle sur votre matiere celeste qui doit être bien legere, puisqu'elle est si fluide? Ce n'est pas à dire, répondis-je, que ce qui est fluide, soit plus leger. Que dites-vous de notre gros Vaisseau, qui avec tout son poids est plus léger que l'eau, puisqu'il y surnage? Je ne veux plus vous dire rien, dit-elle comme en colere, tant que vous aurez le gros Vaisseau. Mais m'assurez-vous bien qu'il n'y ait rien à craindre sur une pirouette aussi legere que vous me faites la Terre? Eh bien, luy répondis-je, faisons porter la Terre par quatre Elephans, comme font les Indiens. Voicy bien un autre Système, s'écria-t-elle. Du moins j'aime ces Gens-là d'avoir pourveu à leur seureté, & fait de bons fondemens, au lieu que nous autres Coperniciens, nous sommes assez inconsideres pour vouloir bien nager à l'aventure dans cette matiere celeste. Je gage que si les Indiens savoient que la Terre fût le moins du monde en peril de se mouvoir, ils doubleroient les Elephans.

P012: Cela le meriteroit bien, repris-je, en riant de sa pensée, il ne faut point s'épargner les Elephans pour dormir en assurance, & si vous en avez besoin pour cette nuit, nous en mettrons dans notre systême autant qu'il vous plaira; ensuite nous les retrancherons peu à peu, à mesure que vous vous rassurerez. Serieusement, reprit-elle, je ne crois pas dés à present qu'ils me soient fort necessaires, & je me sens assez de courage pour oser tourner. Vous irez bien-tost encore plus loin, répliquai-je, vous tournerez avec plaisir, & vous vous ferez sur ce Systême des idées réjouissantes. Quelquefois, par exemple, je me figure que je suis suspendu en l'air, & que j'y demeure sans mouvement pendant que la Terre tourne sous moy en vingt-quatre heures, & que je vois passer sous mes yeux tous ces visages differens, les uns blancs, les autres noirs, les autres bazannez, les autres olivâtres, que je voy d'abord des Chapeaux, & puis des Turbans, & puis des têtes cheveluës, & puis des Têtes rases; tantôt des Villes à clochers, tantôt des Villes à longues aiguilles qui ont des Croissants, tantôt des Villes à Tours de Porcelaine, tantôt de grands Païs qui n'ont que des Cabanes; icy, des vastes Mers; là des Deserts épouvantables; enfin toute cette variété infinie qui est sur la surface de la Terre.
chunks.manualHtml: P009: But, says she again, how is the Earth with all its weight supported in your Celestial matter, which being so fluid must needs be very light? That's not to be allow'd, said I, that what is more fluid is more light. What do you say to your great Vessel; which with all its weight must needs be lighter than the Water, because it swims upon it. Ile say no more to you, says she, as though angry, as long as you have that great Vessel. But can you assure me that there's nothing to be fear'd upon such a Shuttlecock or Whirligigg, as you make the Earth? Well, says I, let us carry the Earth upon four Elephants, as the Indians do. See, says she, another kind of System; yet truly, I like those people that provide for their security, and lay a good foundation; whereas we Copernicans in my opinion are rash enough to attempt to swim at a venture in that Celestial matter. Ile hold a Wager, that if the Indians knew the Earth were in the least danger in the world of being mov'd, they'd double their Elephants 'Twill be worth the while, said I, laughing at her Fancy, never spare an Elephant to sleep in security, and if you have occasion for them this night, we'l put as many in our System as you please, and afterward take them out again by little and little, as you begin to be more and more assured. Seriously, says she, I believe from this time forward I shall not much need them; for I find my self couragious enough to turn. You shall presently, says I, go yet farther, and have delightful Idea's of this System. Sometimes, for example, I fancy with my self that I hang in the Air, and continue there without motion while the Earth turns under me four and twenty hours, and I see pass under me all these different appearances, some white, some black, some swarthy, others tawny, now Hats, then Turbants, some Heads with Hair, others bald, by and by Towns with Steeples, then Towns with long Spires and Crescents, next Towns with Towers of Porcelain, then a large Country that has nothing but Cabins, here a vast Sea, there a frightful Desart, and in fine, all the infinite variety upon the face of the Earth.

explanations: The French idiomatic phrase 'Ce n'est pas à dire' (meaning 'it doesn't necessarily follow that' or 'it is not to say') is simplified to the more forceful 'That's not to be allow'd,' altering the logical nuance. Concurrently, the specific dialogue verb 'répondis-je' (I replied) is simplified to the more common 'said I.'

The French 'que vous me faites la Terre' (implying 'as you present the Earth *to me*') is simplified to 'as you make the Earth.' This omits the explicit personal address ('me'), reducing the direct interpersonal nuance of the Marquise's question.
The specific dialogue verb 'luy répondis-je' (I replied to her/him) is simplified to the more general 'says I,' reducing the vocabulary's descriptive precision for speech attribution.
The expressive dialogue verb 's'écria-t-elle' (she exclaimed/cried out) is simplified to the more neutral and common 'says she,' diminishing the vividness of the character's reaction.

The dialogue verb 'repris-je' (I replied/resumed) is simplified to 'said I.' Additionally, the impersonal French 'il ne faut point s'épargner les Elephans' (one must not be sparing with elephants) is simplified to the direct imperative 'never spare an Elephant,' making the structure more direct and removing the reflexive nuance.

The dialogue verb 'reprit-elle' (she replied/resumed) is simplified to 'says she.' More significantly, the phrase 'pour oser tourner' (to dare to turn) is reduced to 'to turn,' omitting 'oser' (to dare) and thus simplifying the expressed psychological nuance.

The dialogue verb 'répliquai-je' (I replied) is simplified to 'says I.' Furthermore, the clause 'vous tournerez avec plaisir' (you will turn with pleasure) is entirely omitted, reducing text length. The active 'vous vous ferez... des idées' (you will make/form for yourself ideas) is also simplified to 'have... Idea's,' making the phrasing more direct.
The French 'suspendu' (suspended), a somewhat more formal term, is simplified to the more common English verb 'hang.'

The specific phrase 'sous mes yeux' (under my eyes) is generalized to 'under me,' simplifying the visual perspective. Additionally, the concrete term 'visages differens' (different faces) is broadened to 'different appearances,' reducing the specificity and vividness of the original imagery.

chunks.sourceHtml: P013: En verité, dit-elle, tout cela mériteroit bien que l'on donnât vingt-quatre heures de son temps à le voir. Ainsi donc dans le même lieu où nous sommes à present, je ne dis pas dans ce Parc, mais dans ce même lieu, à le prendre dans l'air, il y passe continuellement d'autres Peuples qui prennent notre place, & au bout de vingt-quatre heures nous y revenons.
chunks.manualHtml: P010: Truly, says she, it would be four and twenty hours well spent to see all this; so that in the same place where we are, I do not mean in this Park, but in the same place in the Air, other people are continually passing, and take our place, and in four and twenty hours we return here again.
chunks.aiHtml: P010: Truly, says she, it would be four and twenty hours well spent to see all this; so that in the same place where we are, I do not mean in this Park, but in the same place in the Air, other people are continually passing, and take our place, and in four and twenty hours we return here again.
explanations: The French uses a formal impersonal construction (`l'on donnât` + subjunctive) to express that an action is merited. The English simplifies this to a more direct structure with an adjectival phrase (`hours well spent`) and an infinitive, reducing grammatical complexity.

The French phrase `à le prendre dans l'air` (to consider it abstractly/from an aerial view) is a nuanced idiomatic expression. The English `in the Air` simplifies this to a direct locator, losing the figurative meaning about the mode of consideration.

The French uses an impersonal construction (`il y passe`) and the specific term `Peuples` (Peoples/Nations). The English translation uses a direct active construction (`other people are... passing`) and the more common term `people`, simplifying both sentence structure and vocabulary, and reducing the original's specificity.

chunks.sourceHtml: P014: Copernic, luy répondis-je, ne le comprendroit pas mieux. D'abord il passera par icy des Anglois qui raisonneront peut-être de quelque dessein de Politique avec moins de gayeté que nous ne raisonnons de notre Philosophie; ensuite viendra une grànde Mer, & il se pourra trouver en ce lieu-là quelque Vaisseau qui n'y sera pas si à son aise que nous. Après cela paraîtront des Iroquois, qui mangeront tout vif quelque prisonnier de guerre, qui fera semblant de ne s'en pas soucier; des Femmes de la Terre de Jesso, qui n'employeront tout leur temps qu'à préparer le Repas de leurs Maris, & à se peindre de bleu les lévres & les sourcils pour plaire aux plus vilains Hommes du monde; des Tartares qui iront fort devotement en Pelerinage vers ce Grand Prêtre, qui ne sort jamais d'un lieu obseur, où il n'est éclairé que par des Lampes, à la lumière desquelles on l'adore; de belles Circassiennes qui ne feront aucune façon d'accorder tout au premier venu, hormis ce qu'elles croyent qui appartient essentiellement à leurs Maris; de petits Tartares qui iront voler des Femmes pour les Turcs & pour les Persans; enfin, nous qui debiterons peut-être encore des rêveries.
chunks.manualHtml: P011: Copernicus himself, says I, could not apprehend it better; by and by you'l see some English men pass this way debating some point of Policy, but not so airily as we do our Philosophy; then comes a great Sea, where you'l see a Ship that possibly will not be so much at case as we are; afterward appear the Irroquoi's eating alive some Prisoner of War, who seems not much to heed it; then Women of the Land of Iesso, who spend their whole time in preparing Food for their Husbands, and painting their Lips and Eyebrows blue, to please the most villanous sort of men in the world; next Tartars going in Pilgrimage with great Devotion to that great Priest, who lives always shut up in a Hole where he has no Light, but a Lamp, by which they adore him; then come the fair Circassians, who make no scruple of granting all at first sight? only what they think belongs essentially to their Husbands. Then the little Tartars, who steal Women for the Turks and Persians; and lastly, we who possibly shall yet find other extravagant Inventions.

Then the little Tartars, who steal Women for the Turks and Persians; and lastly, we who possibly shall yet find other extravagant Inventions.
explanations: The initial French impersonal construction "il passera par icy des Anglois" (some English men will pass by here) is simplified to the more direct and conversational "you'l see some English men pass this way". This change makes the narration more immediate for the reader. Additionally, the somewhat formal "quelque dessein de Politique" (some political design/plan) is simplified to the more common "some point of Policy".

Within this segment, the French impersonal and modal construction "il se pourra trouver en ce lieu-là quelque Vaisseau" (there might be found in that place some vessel) is simplified. The translation uses the more direct, active "you'l see a Ship" and the simpler relative adverb "where" (referring to the sea) instead of "en ce lieu-là" (in that place), enhancing readability by reducing structural complexity of that part of the sentence.

The translation simplifies the original French in several ways within this description of the priest: "lieu obseur" (obscure place) becomes the more common and concrete "a Hole"; the passive restrictive clause "où il n'est éclairé que par des Lampes" (where he is lit only by lamps) is rendered as the more direct active construction "where he has no Light, but a Lamp"; and the impersonal "on l'adore" (one adores him) is clarified to "they adore him," making the agent explicit and simplifying the impersonal construction.

The French future tense "iront voler" (will go and steal / will steal), referring to the little Tartars, is simplified to the English simple present tense "steal." This change simplifies the temporal aspect by presenting the action as habitual rather than a specific future event, and also slightly reduces sentence length.

The French "débiterons ... des rêveries" (will utter/recount daydreams/fantasies) is translated as "shall yet find other extravagant Inventions." This simplifies the original by replacing the abstract concept of "rêveries" (musings/daydreams) and the nuanced action of "débiter" (uttering/recounting them) with the more concrete noun "Inventions" and the simpler action "find."

chunks.sourceHtml:
P015: Il est assez plaisant, dit la Marquise, d'imaginer ce que vous venez de me dire; mais si je voyois tout cela d'en haut, je voudrais avoir la liberté de hâter ou d'arrêter le mouvement de la Terre, selon que les objets me plairont plus ou moins, & je vous assure que je ferais passer bien vite ceux qui s'embarrassent de Politique, ou qui mangent leurs Ennemis; mais il y en a d'autres pour qui j'aurois de la curiosité. J'en aurais pour ces Belles Circassiennes, par exemple, elles ont un usage qui mr paroit assez particulier. C'est qu'elle sont si belles, luy dis-je, que leurs Maris trovent dans leurs faveurs un superflu qu'ils abandonnent aux Etrangers. Les Femmes de ces Païs icy sont donc bien laides aux prix d'elles, reprit la Marquise, car le Maris ne relâchent rien. Cela est cause qu'on prend davantage, repliqay-je, au lieu que...Taisez-vous, interrompit-elle, je ne veux plus dire de folies, aussi bien il me vient une difficulté sérieuse. Si la Terre tourne, nous changeons d'air à chaque moment, & nous respirons toûjours celuy d'un autre Païs. Nullement, Madame, répondis-je, l'air qui environne la Terre ne s'étend que jusqu'à une certaine hauteur, peut-être jusqu'à 20 lieües, il nous suit, & tourne avec nous. Vous avez veu mille fois l'ouvrage d'un Ver à soye, ou ces Coques que ces petits animaux travaillent avec tant d'art pour s'y emprisonner. Elles sont d'une soye fort serrée, mais elles sont couvertes d'un certain duvet fort leger & fort lâche. C'est ainsi que la Terre, qui est assez solide, est couverte depuis sa surface jusqu'à vinght lieües de hauteur tout au plus, d'une espèce de duvet, qui est l'air, & toute la Coque de Ver à soye tourne en même temps. Au-delà de l'air est la matiere celeste, incomparablement plus pure, plus subtile, & même plus agitée que luy.

P016: Vous me présentez la Terre sous des idées bien méprisables, dit la Marquise. C'est pourtant sur cette Coque de Ver à soye qu'il se fait de si grands Travaux, de si grandes Guerres, & qu'il règne de tous côtés une si grande agitation. Oüy, répondis-je, & pendant ce temps-là la Nature qui n'entre point en connaissance de tous ces petits mouvements particuliers, nous emporte tous ensemble d'un mouvement général, & se joüe de la petite boule.

P017: Il me semble, reprit-elle, qu'il est ridicule d'être sur quelque chose qui tourne, & de se tourmenter tant; mais le malheur est qu'on n'est pas assuré qu'on tourne; car enfin, à ne vous rien celer, toutes les précautions que vous prenez pour empêcher qu'on ne s'aperçoive du mouvement de la Terre, me sont suspectes. Est-il possible qu'il ne laissera pas quelque petite marque sensible à laquelle on le reconnaisse?

P018: Les mouvements les plus naturels, répondis-je, & les plus ordinaires, sont ceux qui se font le moins sentir, & cela est vray jusque dans la Morale. Le mouvement de l'Amour propre nous est si naturel, que le plus souvent nous ne le sentons pas, & que nous croyons agir par d'autres principes. Ah! vous moralisez, dit- elle, quand il est question de Physique, cela s'appelle bâiller. Retirons-nous, aussi bien en voilà assez pour la premiere fois. Demain nous reviendrons icy, vous avec vos Systêmes, & moi avec mon Ignorance.
chunks.manualHtml: P012: 'Tis pleasant enough, says the Marchioness, to imagin all this you tell me; but if I saw it all from an height, I should wish to have the liberty to hasten or stop the motion of the Earth, according as the Objects pleas'd or displeas'd me; and, I assure you, I should presently turn away those that trouble their Heads with Policy, or eat their Enemies; but for some others I should have a curiosity; particularly for those fair Circassians, they have a custom which methinks is very particular. 'Tis, says I, because they are so fair that their Husbands find in their favours a superfluity, which they allow to strangers. Then the Women of this Country, says the Marchioness, are very ugly, compared with them, for the Husbands here give no liberty at all. That's the reason, says I, they take more, whereas-Hold your peace, says she, I'le talk no more follies; besides I have a serious difficulty come in my head, If the Earth turn, we change Air every moment, and breath that of another Contry. Not at all, Madam, says I, the Air which surrounds the Earth extends but to a certain height, it may be twenty leagues or so, and it follows and turns along with us. You have a thousand times seen the Work of a Silkworm, or those Cods of Silk which those little Animals work with so much Art for their own Prison, they are of a close wrought Silk, but are covered with a certain Down very light and loose. Just so the Earth. which is solid enough, is cover'd from the surface about twenty leagues high at most, with a kind of Down, which is the Air; This and all the other Cod of the Silkworm turns at the same time. Beyond the Air is the Celestial matter incomparably more pure, more subtil, and likewise more in motion than it. You give me, said the Marchioness, Idea's of the Earth contemptible enough; is it then upon this shell of a Silkworm that we labour and toil, and fight, and make such a noise on all hands as we do? 'Tis even so, said I, and in the mean time Nature that takes no notice of those little tle particular motions, carrys us altogether with one general movement, and sports her self with the lit-Ball. To me, says she, it seems something ridiculous to be seated upon a thing that turns? and torment ones self so much; but the mischief is, we are not fully assur'd that we turn; for to tell you truth, notwithstanding all those precautions you have us'd, that a man should not perceive the motion of the Earth, I am still very doubtful. Is it possible it should not be discover'd by some little mark or other? The most natural motions, said I, and the most ordinary, are those which are least perceiv'd, and this is true even in Morality it self. The motion of Self-love is so natural to us, that most commonly we are not at all sensible of it, and think that we are acted by some other principle. Ah! says she, when there's a Question in Natural Philosophy, you begin to moralize, and that's call'd Bantring. Let us now retire, for this is enough for once. To morrow we'l come here again, you with your Systems, and I with my Ignorance.

explanations: The French "venir de + infinitive" construction ("vous venez de me dire," meaning "you have just told me") indicating immediate past action is simplified to the simple present "you tell me." This reduces grammatical complexity and makes the utterance more direct, though slightly less precise in timing.

The French reflexive verb construction "s'embarrassent de Politique" (get entangled/bother themselves with Politics) is simplified by using the more colloquial English idiom "trouble their Heads with Policy," which employs more common vocabulary and a less complex grammatical structure.

The French phrase "il y en a d'autres pour qui" (there are others for whom) is simplified to the more concise "for some others," reducing structural complexity by replacing an existential clause followed by a relative pronoun with a simpler prepositional phrase.

The French construction "J'en aurais pour" (implying "My curiosity would extend to") is simplified to the more direct adverbial phrase "particularly for," which uses more common vocabulary and simplifies the original's pronominal reference ("en").

The French "ne relâchent rien" (literally "do not relax/release anything," meaning they don't concede anything) is simplified by using the more explicit and common English phrase "give no liberty at all," which clarifies the meaning directly with more familiar vocabulary.

The formal French causative "Cela est cause que..." (That is the cause that...) is simplified to the more common and direct colloquialism "That's the reason...". The impersonal "on prend" (one takes) is also simplified to the more concrete "they take", making the overall phrase more accessible.

The French "il me vient une difficulté" (a difficulty comes to me) is rendered with the more colloquial English idiom "I have a difficulty come in my head." This simplifies the impersonal "il me vient" structure to a possessive construction, which is more common in conversational English.

The French "peut-être jusqu'à" (perhaps up to) is simplified through the addition of the colloquial qualifier "or so". This makes the expression of approximation more conversational and uses common English phrasing, slightly reducing formality.

The French reflexive verb construction "pour s'y emprisonner" (to imprison themselves therein) is simplified to a prepositional phrase with a noun "for their own Prison." This shift from a verbal to a nominal construction makes the phrasing more direct and structurally less complex.

The French "Vous me présentez la Terre sous des idées bien méprisables" (You present the Earth to me under very contemptible ideas) is simplified. "présentez... sous des idées" becomes the more direct "give me... Idea's" using a more common verb. The intensifier "bien" (very) is rendered as "enough," which can be a less forceful and simpler modification.

The French impersonal constructions "il se fait de si grands Travaux, de si grandes Guerres" (such great Works/Wars are made/done) and "il règne... une si grande agitation" (there reigns... such great agitation) are simplified. The translation shifts to active voice with the personal pronoun "we" ("we labour and toil, and fight"). Furthermore, the abstract noun "une si grande agitation" is replaced by the more concrete and colloquial phrase "make such a noise on all hands," simplifying vocabulary and imagery.

The complex French idiom "n'entre point en connaissance de" (literally "does not at all enter into knowledge of," meaning doesn't become aware of/doesn't consider) is simplified to the much more common and direct English idiom "takes no notice of."

The French statement "me sont suspectes" (are suspect to me), which directly qualifies the precautions, is simplified. The translation shifts the focus to the speaker's internal state with "I am still very doubtful." This expresses a similar sentiment of distrust using a more common adjective ("doubtful") and a simpler subjective predication compared to the object-focused "sont suspectes".

The French construction involving a future indicative "ne laissera pas" (will not leave) and a subjunctive in the relative clause "à laquelle on le reconnaisse" (by which one might recognize it) is simplified. The English uses a modal "should not be discover'd" and the colloquial addition "or other," making the overall sentence structure more direct and less grammatically intricate by avoiding the complex relative clause.

The French reflexive construction "se font le moins sentir" (literally "make themselves felt the least," or are least felt) is simplified to the more straightforward English passive voice "are least perceiv'd," reducing structural complexity.

The French "aussi bien en voilà assez pour la premiere fois" (besides, that's [of it] enough for the first time) is simplified. "aussi bien" (besides/also) is rendered as "for" (conjunction). "en voilà assez" (that's enough of it) becomes "this is enough," and "pour la premiere fois" (for the first time) is simplified to the concise idiom "for once." This makes the phrasing more direct and uses more common expressions.

chunks.sourceHtml: P019: En retournant au Château je luy dis pour épuiser la matiere des Systêmes, qu'il y en avoit un troisiéme inventé par Tycho Brahé qui, voulant absolument que la Terre fût immobile, la plaçoit au centre du Monde, & faisoit tourner autour d'elle le Soleil, autour duquel tournoient toutes les autres Planètes, parce que depuis les nouvelles Découvertes, il n'y avoit pas moyen de faire tourner les Planètes autour de la Terre. Mais la Marquise, qui a le discernement vif & prompt, jugea qu'il y avoit trop d'affectation à exempter la Terre de tourner autour du Soleil, puisqu'on n'en pouvait pas exempter tant d'autres grands corps; que le Soleil n'étoit plus si propre à tourner autour de la Terre, depuis que toutes les Planètes tournaient autour de luy; que ce systême ne pouvoit être propre tout au plus qu'à soûtenir l'Immobilité de la Terre, quand on avoit bien envie de la soûtenir, & nullement à la persuader; & enfin il fut résolu que nous nous en tiendrions à celuy de Copernic, qui est plus uniforme & plus riant, & n'a aucun mélange de préjugé. En effet la simplicité dont il est, vous persuade, & sa hardiesse vous fait plaisir.
chunks.manualHtml: P013: In our return to the Castle, I told her, to carry on the business of Systems, that there was a third sort invented by Tycho Brahe, who being absolutely of opinion that the Earth was immovable, plac'd it in the Center of the World, and made the Sun turn about it, and all the Planets about the Sun; because since the new Discoveries, there was no way left to make the Planets turn about the Earth. But the Marchioness, who is of a quick and lively Judgment, was of opinion that it was too much Affectation to exempt the Earth from turning about the Sun, since so many other great Bodies could not be exempted; That it was not so proper for the Sun to turn about the Earth, since all the Planets turn'd about him. That that System was at best only propet to maintain the Immobility of the Earth, when any one had a mind to maintain it, but not at all to persuade it. In fine, we resolv'd to hold to that of Copernicus, which is more uniform, and more delightful, and has no mixture of prejudice. In effect the Simplicity of it persuades, and the Boldness delights.

explanations: The French phrase "pour épuiser la matiere des Systêmes" (to exhaust the subject of Systems) is a more formal and literary expression. The English translation "to carry on the business of Systems" simplifies this by using more common vocabulary and a more pragmatic, less academic turn of phrase, suggesting continuation rather than exhaustive exploration.

The French uses an impersonal passive construction "il fut résolu que..." (it was resolved that...) followed by a reflexive pronominal verb "nous nous en tiendrions à" (we would stick to/abide by it). The English translation simplifies this complex structure to a more direct active voice construction "we resolv'd to hold to...", making the sentence easier to process.

The French phrase "la simplicité dont il est" (literally, "the simplicity of which it is" or "the simplicity that it possesses") uses a relative pronoun construction common in formal French to denote a characteristic. The English translation "the Simplicity of it" simplifies this by using a more direct and common prepositional phrase.

The original French presents the Marquise's entire reasoning and the subsequent resolution as one very long, complex sentence, structured with multiple subordinate clauses ("qu'il y avoit...", "que le Soleil...", "que ce systême...") dependent on "jugea que". The English translation breaks this single complex sentence into several shorter sentences (e.g., new sentences starting with "That it was not so proper..." and "That that System..."). This division significantly simplifies the syntactic structure, making the Marquise's arguments easier to follow by presenting them as a sequence of distinct points rather than a single, elaborate deduction.

The French adjective "riant" (literally "laughing" or "smiling") when applied to a system, carries a specific, somewhat poetic nuance meaning attractive, pleasing, or cheerful. The English translation "more delightful" uses a more common and general positive adjective. This simplifies the original by opting for a less figurative term, potentially reducing the specific imagery or stylistic richness of "riant" in this context.

chunks.sourceHtml: P020: SECOND SOIR. Que la Lune est une Terre habitée.
chunks.manualHtml: P014: THE Second Evening.
chunks.aiHtml: P014: THE Second Evening.
explanations: The English translation simplifies the heading by omitting the descriptive subtitle 'Que la Lune est une Terre habitée' (That the Moon is an inhabited Earth), which is present in the original French. This reduces the informational density of the heading, making it shorter and less thematically explicit than the source.

chunks.sourceHtml: P021: Le lendemain au matin dès que l'on pût entrer dans l'Appartement de la Marquise, j'envoyai savoir de ses nouvelles, & lui demander si elle avoit pû dormir en tournant. Elle me fit répondre qu'elle etoit déjà toute accoûtumée à cette allûre de la Terre, & qu'elle avoit passé la nuit aussi tranquillement qu'auroit pû faire Copernic lui-même. Quelque temps après il vint chez elle du monde qui y demeura jusqu'au soir, selon l'ennuyeuse coutume de la Campagne. Encore leur fut-on bien obligé, car la Campagne leur donnoit aussi le droit de pousser leur visite jusqu'au lendemain, s'ils eussent voulu, & ils eurent l'honnêteté de ne le pas faire. Ainsi la Marquise & moi nous nous retrouvâmes libres le Soir. Nous allâmes encore dans le Parc, & la conversation ne manqua pas de tourner aussitôt sur nos Sistêmes. Elle les avoit si bien conceus, qu'elle dédaigna d'en parler une seconde fois, & elle voulut que je la menasse a quelque chose de nouveau. Et bien donc, luy dis-je, puisque le Soleil, qui est présentement immobile, a cessé d'être Planète, & que la Terre qui se meut autour de lui, a commencé d'en être une, vous ne serez pas si surprise d'entendre dire que la Lune est une Terre comme celle-cy, & qu'apparemment elle est habitée. Je n'ay pourtant jamais oüy parler de la Lune habitée, dit-elle, que comme d'une folie & d'une vision. C'en est peut-être une aussi, répondis-je. Je ne prens parti dans ces choses-là que comme on en prend dans les Guerres Civiles, où l'incertitude de ce qui peut arriver, fait qu'on entretient toûjours des intelligences dans le party opposé, & qu'on a des ménagemens avec ses Ennemis mêmes. Pour moi, quoyque je voye la Lune habitée, je ne laisse pas de vivre civilement avec ceux qui ne le croyent pas, — & je me tiens toujours en état de me pouvoir ranger à leur opinion avec honneur, si elle avoit le dessus; mais en attendant qu'ils ayent sur nous quelque avantage considérable, voyci ce qui m'a mis du côté des Habitans de la Lune.
chunks.manualHtml:
P015: NExt Morning, as soon as the Marchioness could be seen, I sent to know how she did, and to ask her if she could sleep well turning? She sent me word, that she was so well accustomed to that sort of motion of the Earth, that she pass'd the night as quietly as Copernicus himself could have done. Soon after she had Company came to her, who, according to the troublesome Custome in the Country, stay'd with her till Evening; and they were obliging in that too; for by the Custom in the Country they had a right to continue their Visits till next morning if they pleas'd; but they were so honest as to be gone. So that the Marchioness and I found our selves at liberty in the Evening. We took our Walk again into the Park, and our Conversation fail'd not to return presently to our Systems. She had apprehended them so well, that she disdain'd to discourse of them a second time, but would needs have me lead her to some new matter.

P016: Well then, said I, since the Sun, that is now immovable, is no more a Planet, and that the Earth, that moves about him, has begun to be one, you will not be so surpriz'd to hear that the Moon is an Earth like this, and that apparently she is inhabited. Truly, says she, I never yet heard speak of the Moon's being inhabited, but only as a Folly and a Vision. Possibly 'tis such, said I. I do not ingage in things of that nature, but as men ingage in a Civil War, where the incertainty of the event makes them still hold inteligence with the opposite Party, and maintain an Intrigue with the very Enemy. For my part, though I should see the Moon inhabited, yet I would still live civilly with those that do not believe it, and I preserve my self in such a condition, that I may with Honour subscribe to their Opinion, if it prevail. But in the mean while, till they get some considerable advantages over us, see what it is has drawn me to side with the Inhabitants of the Moon.

The French phrase 'C'en est peut-être une aussi' (It is perhaps one [of them] also) is condensed and simplified. 'Peut-être... aussi' (perhaps... also) becomes the single adverb 'Possibly,' and 'C'en est une' (it is one of them) becomes the concise ''tis such,' reducing text length and density.

chunks.sourceHtml: P022: Suposons qu'il n'y ait jamais eu nul commerce entre Paris & Saint-Denis, & qu'un Bourgeois de Paris, qui ne sera jamais sorty de sa Ville, soit sur les Tours de Notre Dame, & voye Saint-Denis de loin; on luy demandera s'il croit que Saint-Denis soit habité comme Paris. Il répondra hardiment que non; car, dira- t-il, je vois bien les Habitans de Paris, mais ceux de Saint-Denis je ne les voy point, & on n'en a jamais entendu parler. Il y aura quelqu'un qui luy representera qu'à la vérité quand on est sur les Tours de Notre-Dame, on ne voit pas les Habitans de Saint-Denis, mais que l'éloignement en est cause; que tout ce qu'on peut voir de Saint-Denis ressemble fort à Paris, que Saint Denis a des Clochers, des Maisons, des Murailles, & qu'il pourrait bien encore ressembler à Paris pour ce qui est d'être habité. Tout cela ne gagnera rien sur mon Bourgeois, il s'obstinera toûjours à soûtenir que Saint-Denis n'est point habité, puisqu'il n'y voit personne. Notre Saint-Denis c'est la Lune, & chacun de nous est ce Bourgeois de Paris, qui n'est jamais sorty de sa Ville.
chunks.manualHtml: P017: Let us suppose that there was never any Commerce between Paris and St. Denis (a Town about three miles from Paris) and that a Burgess of Paris, who never stirr'd out of the Town, should from the top of Nostre Dame see Saint Denis at a distance, the question is put him, whether he believes that Saint Denis is inhabited as Paris is or not, he'l confidently say no; for, says he, I see plainly the Inhabitants of Paris, but those of Saint Denis I do not see at all, nor ever heard speak of them. Some standerby may tell him, that 'tis true indeed that from the top of Nostre Dame the Inhabitants of Saint Denis are not seen, but that 'tis the distance is the cause, that all that can be seen of Saint Denis is very like Paris, that Saint Denis has Steeples, and Houses and Walls, and possibly may likewise resemble Paris in being inhabited, all this will not prevail with my honest Burgess, he's still obstinate that Saint Denis cannot be inhabited, because he sees not a man in it. Our Saint Denis is the Moon, and every one of us is just such a Burgess of Paris that never stirr'd out of the Town.

explanations: The French uses the futur antérieur tense "ne sera jamais sorty" (literally "will never have gone out"), which can express a strong assumption or a defining characteristic projected to hold true. The English translation uses the simple past "never stirr'd," simplifying this nuanced temporal aspect into a more direct statement of past fact, thereby using a more common and less grammatically complex structure for such a description in English.

The French impersonal pronoun "on" (one/people) in "on n'en a jamais entendu parler" (one has never heard speak of them) is omitted in the English translation. The verb "heard" is instead directly linked to the burgess as the implied subject from the preceding clause ("I... nor ever heard"). This simplifies the sentence structure by maintaining a consistent first-person subject and avoiding a shift to an impersonal construction, making the statement more direct.

The French periphrastic phrase "pour ce qui est d'être habité" (literally, "for that which is of being inhabited" or "as for being inhabited") is simplified to the more concise English prepositional phrase "in being inhabited." Additionally, the modal construction "pourrait bien encore ressembler" (could well still/also resemble) is condensed to "possibly may likewise resemble," streamlining the phrasing and reducing its density.

The French construction "il s'obstinera toûjours à soûtenir que" (he will always/still persist in maintaining that) involves a reflexive verb followed by a preposition and an infinitive. This is simplified in the English translation to "he's still obstinate that," which uses a more direct adjectival phrase with a copula (and includes the contraction "he's"). This change reduces the verbosity and structural complexity of the original French.

chunks.sourceHtml: P023: Ah! interrompit la Marquise, vous nous faites tort, nous ne sommes point si sots que votre Bourgeois. Puis qu'il voit que Saint-Denis est tout fait comme Paris, il faut qu'il ait perdu la raison pour ne le pas croire habité; mais la Lune n'est point du tout faite comme la Terre. Prenez garde, Madame, repris-je, car s'il faut que la Lune ressemble en tout à la Terre, vous voilà dans l'obligation de croire la Lune habitée. J'avoüe, répondit-elle, qu'il n'y aura pas moyen de s'en dispenser, & je vous vois un air de confiance qui me fait déjà peur. Les deux mouvements de la Terre, dont je ne me fusse jamais doutée, me rendent timide sur tout le reste; mais pourtant seroit-il bien possible que la Terre fût lumineuse comme la Lune? Car il faut cela pour leur ressemblance. Hélas! Madame, répliquay-je, être lumineux n'est pas si grand-chose que vous pensez. Il n'y a que le Soleil en qui cela soit une qualité considérable. Il est lumineux par luy- même, & en vertu d'une nature particulière qu'il a; mais les Planètes n'éclairent que parce qu'elles sont éclairées de luy. Il envoye sa lumière à la Lune, elle nous la renvoye, & il faut que la Terre renvoye aussi à la Lune la lumière du Soleil; il n'y a pas plus loin de la Terre à la Lune, que de la Lune à la Terre.
chunks.manualHtml: P018: Oh! said the Marchioness, you do us wrong, we are not so dull as your Burgess; he that sees Saint Denis wholly made like Paris, must needs have lost his Reason, not to believe that 'tis inhabited; but the Moon is not at all made like the Earth. Have a care, Madam, said I, for if I prove that the Moon must resemble the Earth, you are then downright oblig'd to believe that the Moon is inhabited. I acknowledge, says she, there will be no way to avoid it; and I observe in your looks an air of confidence that makes me half afraid. The two motions of the Earth, of which I shall never make any doubt, make me timorous in all the rest; but however, is it possible that the Earth should be luminous as the Moon is? for that must be to make up the resemblance. Alas, Madam, said I, to be luminous is not so a great matter as you imagine; there is only the Sun in which that quality is considerable; he is luminous in himself, by vertue of a nature peculiar to him, but the Planets give no Light, but as they are inlighten'd by him. He sends his Light to the Moon, she returns it to us, and it must needs be likewise, that the Earth sends the Light of the Sun to the Moon; for 'tis no farther from the Earth to the Moon, than from the Moon to the Earth.

chunks.sourceHtml:
P024: Mais, dit la Marquise, la Terre est-elle aussi propre que la Lune à renvoyer la lumiere du Soleil? Je vous vois toûjours, pour la Lune, repris-je, un reste d'estime dont vous ne sauriez vous défaire. La lumiere est composée de petites balles qui bondissent sur ce qui est solide, & retournent d'un autre côté, au lieu qu'elles passent au travers de ce qui leur presente des ouvertures en ligne droite, comme l'air ou le verre. Ainsi ce qui fait que la Lune nous éclaire, c'est qu'elle est un Corps dur & solide, qui nous renvoye ces petites balles. Or je croy que vous ne contesterez pas à la Terre cette même dureté e& cette même solidité. Admirez donc ce que c'est que d'être posté avantageusement. Parce que la Lune est éloignée de nous, nous ne la voyons que comme un Corps lumineux, & nous ignorons que ce soit une grosse masse, toute semblable à la Terre. Au contraire, parce que la Terre a le malheur que nous la voyons de trop prés, elle ne nous paroît qu'une grosse masse, propre seulement à fournir de la pâture aux Animaux, & nous ne nous apercevons pas qu'elle est lumineuse, faute de nous pouvoir mettre à quelque distance d'elle. Cela va de la même maniere, dit la Marquise, que quand nous sommes frapés de l'éclat des Conditions; élevées au-dessus des nôtres, & que nous ne voyons pas, qu'au fond elles se ressemblent toutes extrêmement.

P025: C'est la même chose, répondis-je. Nous voulons juger de tout, & nous sommes toûjours dans un mauvais point de veüe. Nous voulons juger de nous, nous en sommes trop près; nous voulons juger des autres, nous en sommes trop loin. Qui serait entre la Lune & la Terre, ce seroit la vraye place pour les bien voir. Il faudroit être simplement spectateur du Monde, & non pas Habitant. Je ne me consoleray jamais, dit-elle, de l'injustice que nous faisons à la Terre, & de la préoccupation trop favorable où nous sommes pour la Lune, si vous ne m'assurez que les Gens de la Lune ne connaissent pas mieux leurs avantages que nous connoissons les nôtres, & qu'ils prennent notre Terre pour un Astre, sans savoir que leur habitation en est un aussi. Pour cela, repris-je, je vous le garantis. Nous leur paraissons faire assez regulièrement nos fonctions d'Astres. Il est vray qu'ils ne nous voyent pas décrire un Cercle autour d'eux; mais il n'importe, voicy ce que c'est. La moitié de la Lune qui se trouva tournée vers nous au commencement du Monde, y a toûjours eté tournée depuis; elle ne nous présente jamais que ces yeux, cette bouche, & le reste de ce visage que notre imagination luy compose sur le fondement des tâches qu'elle nous montre. Si l'autre moitié opposée se presentoit à nous, d'autres tâches differemment arrangées, nous feroient sans doute imaginer quelque autre figure. Ce n'est pas que la Lune ne tourne sur elle-même, elle y tourne en autant de temps qu'autour de la Terre, c'est à dire, en un mois; mais lors qu'elle fait une partie de ce tremblement, & de s'imaginer que nous avons dans le Ciel comme un mouvement de Pendule qui va & vient.
chunks.manualHtml:
P019: But, says the Marchioness, is the Earth as proper as the Moon to reflect the Light of the Sun? I observe, said I, that you have still a good thought for the Moon, which you cannot part with. The Light is composed of little Balls, that rebound from any thing that is solid, whereas they pass in a straight line through any thing that opens to them, as the Air, or Glass. So that hence it is that the Moon gives us Light, because she is a hard solid body that reflects those little Balls upon us. Now I believe you will not at all contest the solidity of the Earth. Admire then what it is to be advantagiously plac'd. The Moon being so far distant from us, we only behold it as a luminous body, and know not that 'tis a great mass like the Earth. On the contrary, because the Earth has the ill luck to be seen by us near at hand, she appears to us a great mass fit for nothing but to feed Cattel, and cannot discern that she is luminous, because we cannot set our selves at distance enough from her. Just so, said she, we are dazl'd with the lustre of Conditions more elevated than our own, and never discern that in the bottom they are extremely alike.

P020: 'Tis even so, said I we would judge of all, but are still ill placed to take our view; in judging of our selves we are too near, and in judging of others too far off. The middle place between the Moon and the Earth is the best to take a right prospect of both; and better it would be, to be simply a Spectator of the World than an Inhabitant. I shall never be comforted, says she, for the Injustice we do the Earth, and our too much partiality to the Moon, unless you assure me that the people of the Moon, have no more knowledge of their Advantages than we have of ours, and that they take our Earth for a Star, without knowing that their own Habitation is so likewise. I'le warrant you for that, said I, we appear to them to perform our function of a Star regularly enough: 'tis true they do not see us describe a Circle about them; but 'tis no matter, the thing is this; The half of the Moon which was turn'd towards us at the beginning of the World, has continued so ever since, she still shews the same Eyes, the same Mouth, and all the rest of the Face, which those Spots we discern in her, frame in our Imagination; if we saw the other half, other kind of Spots, in different posture, would doubtless create in our Imagination other kind of Figures. 'Tis not that the Moon does not turn about her self, 'tis certain she turns in just so much time as she turns about the Earth, that is, in a month. But when she has made one part of that turn about her self, and that she ought to hide, for example, one Cheek of that pretended Face from us, and appear some other thing, she makes the like part of her Circle about the Earth, and putting her self in a new point of sight, shews us still the same Cheek. So that the Moon, that in respect of the Sun and other Stars, turns about her self, in respect of us turns not all. She sees them all rise and set in the space of fifteen days, but our Earth she sees daily hanging in the same place of Heaven. This seeming Immobility agrees not well with a body which ought to pass for a Star; but 'tis true likewise that she her self is not perfect. The Moon has a certain wavering motion (motus libratorius) which is the cause that a little corner of her Face is sometimes hid, and a little corner of the opposite side appears. Now I'le undertake, that she imputes that wavering to us, and imagines that we have a movement to and fro in the Heavens like a Pendulum.

explanations: The French "un reste d'estime" (a remnant of esteem) is simplified to the more common and less formal "a good thought." The somewhat elaborate phrasing "dont vous ne sauriez vous défaire" (from which you would not know how to rid yourself) is also rendered more simply as "which you cannot part with," making the language more accessible.

The translator simplifies by omitting "cette même dureté" (this same hardness), reducing the original's pairing of near-synonyms ("dureté et solidité") to just "solidity." This reduces the density of the text slightly.

The general French term "fournir de la pâture aux Animaux" (to provide fodder/pasture to Animals) is simplified to the more specific and common English phrase "to feed Cattel." This makes the concept more concrete and arguably simpler for the intended audience.

The initial French phrase "Cela va de la même maniere... que quand" (That goes in the same manner... as when) is simplified to the more concise "Just so...". The French construction "& que nous ne voyons pas, qu'au fond..." (and that we do not see, that at bottom...) involving a subordinate clause introduced by 'que' following another 'que' is simplified to a more direct single clause "and never discern that in the bottom...", streamlining the sentence structure for readability.

The French conditional and somewhat impersonal construction "Qui serait entre la Lune & la Terre, ce seroit la vraye place..." (He who would be between the Moon & the Earth, it would be the true place...) is simplified into a more direct, declarative statement: "The middle place between the Moon and the Earth is the best...", making the sentence structure less complex.

The somewhat periphrastic and formal French phrase "de la préoccupation trop favorable où nous sommes pour la Lune" (of the too favorable preoccupation that we have for the Moon) is simplified to the more concise and direct English possessive phrase "our too much partiality to the Moon."

The French "ne... que" construction (meaning 'only') in "elle ne nous présente jamais que ces yeux" is simplified to "she still shews the same Eyes". More significantly, the clause "que notre imagination luy compose sur le fondement des tâches qu'elle nous montre" (that our imagination composes for it based on the foundation of the spots it shows us) is rephrased. The English "which those Spots we discern in her, frame in our Imagination" simplifies the agency by making "Spots" the active framer, and the formal "sur le fondement des" (on the foundation of) is replaced by a more direct conceptual link, making the sentence flow more smoothly.

The phrase "l'autre moitié opposée se presentoit à nous" (the other opposite half presented itself to us) is simplified to "if we saw the other half." This uses a more common verb form ("saw" vs. the reflexive "se presentoit à nous") and removes the slightly redundant "opposée" (opposite), as "other half" often implies opposition.

The French "& de s'imaginer" (and to imagine/and of imagining) is an infinitive phrase that creates a syntactically somewhat loose or dependent clause. The English translation simplifies this by providing a finite verb "imagines" and making its subject (the Moon, implied from the translator's preceding elaborations) explicit. This results in a more direct and easily understood sentence structure, resolving a potential ambiguity or awkwardness present in the (possibly incomplete or corrupted) source text fragment.

chunks.sourceHtml: P026: Toutes ces Planètes, dit la Marquise, sont faites comme nous, qui rejetons toûjours sur les autres ce qui est en nous-mêmes. La Terre dit: Ce n'est pas moy qui tourne, c'est le Soleil. La Lune dit, _Ce n'est pas moy qui tremble, c'est la Terre. Il y a bien de l'erreur par tout. Je ne vous conseille pas d'entreprendre d'y rien réformer, répondis-je, il vaut mieux que vous acheviez de vous convaincre de l'entiere ressemblance de la Terre & de la Lune. Représentez-vous ces deux grandes Boules suspendües dans les Cieux. Vous savez que le Soleil éclaire toûjours une moitié des Corps qui sont ronds, & que l'autre moitié est dans l'ombre. Il y a donc toûjours une moitié, tant de la Terre que de la Lune, qui est éclairée du Soleil, c'est à dire, qui a le jour, & une autre moitié qui est dans la nuit. Remarquez d'ailleurs que comme une Balle a moins de force & de vitesse après qu'elle a été donner contre une muraille qui l'a renvoyée d'un autre côté, de même la lumière s'affoiblit lors qu'elle a été réfléchie par quelque Corps. Cette lumière blanchâtre qui nous vient de la Lune, est la lumière même du Soleil, mais elle ne peut venir de la Lune à nous que par une réflexion. Elle a donc beaucoup perdu de la force & de la vivacité qu'elle avoit lorsqu'elle étoit receüe directement sur la Lune, & cette lumière éclatante que nous recevons du Soleil & que la Terre reflechit sur la Lune, ne doit plus être qu'une lumiere blanchâtre quand elle y est arrivée. Ainsi ce qui nous paroit lumineux dans la Lune, & qui nous éclaire pendant nos nuits, ce sont des parties de la Lune qui ont le jour; & les parties de la Terre qui ont le jour lors qu'elles sont tournées vers les parties de la Lune qui ont la nuit les éclairent aussi. Tout dépend de la manière dont la Lune & la Terre se regardent. Dans les premiers jours du mois que l'on ne voit pas la Lune, c'est qu'elle est entre le Soleil & nous, & qu'elle marche de jour avec le Soleil. Il faut necessairement que toute sa moitié qui a le jour, soit tournée vers le Soleil, & que toute sa moitié qui a la nuit, soit tournée vers nous. Nous n'avons garde de voir cette moitié qui n'a aucune lumière pour se faire voir. Mais cette moitié de la Lune qui a la nuit, étant tournée vers la moitié de la Terre qui a le jour, nous voit sans être veüe, & nous voit sous la même figure que nous voyons la Pleine Lune. C'est alors pour les Gens de la Lune Pleine Terre, s'il est permis de parler ainsi. Ensuite la Lune qui avance sur son Cercle d'un mois, se dégage de dessous le Soleil, & commence à tourner vers nous un petit coin de sa moitié éclairée, & voilà le Croissant. Alors aussi les parties de la Lune qui ont la nuit commencent à ne plus voir toute la moitié de la Terre qui a le jour, & nous sommes en Décours pour elles.
chunks.manualHtml: P021: All these Planets, says the Marchioness, I find are made like us, who are still charging others with what is in our selves; the Earth says, 'Tis not I that turn, 'tis the Sun: The Moon says, 'Tis not I that waver, 'tis the Earth: there's faults enough every where. I would not advise you, said I, to attempt a Reformation: 'Tis better that you fully convince your self of the perfect resemblance of the Earth and Moon. Represent to your self those two great Bouls hanging in the Heavens. You know that the Sun always enlightens one half of a Spherical body, and that the other half is in the Shadow. Then the Sun daily enlightens one half both of the Earth and the Moon, viz. in one half 'tis day, in the other night. Observe moreover, that as a Ball loses its force when reverberated from a Wall, so likewise the light grows weak when reflected from another body. That pale Light which we receive from the Moon, is the very Light of the Sun, but it cannot come to us but by Reflection. It must therefore lose much of the force and vivacity it had when it fell directly upon the Moon. So that glittering Light which we receive directly from the Sun, and is reflected from the Earth to the Moon, must needs be but a pale Light when it reaches thither. So that which appears to us luminous in the Moon, and which enlightens us in our nights, is the parts of the Moon where it is then day, and the parts of the Earth where it is day being turn'd towards the parts of the Moon where it is night, inlightens them likewise; all depends upon the manner of the Moon and Earths regarding one another. In the first days of a month, when the Moon is not seen, she is then between the Sun and us, and moves by day along with the Sun. It must needs be, that the half of her where it is day is turn'd toward the Sun, and her other half that is benighted is turn'd towards us. We do not look to see that half that has no Light to shew it self, but that half of the Moon that is benighted being turn'd toward the half of the Earth where it is day, sees us without being seen, and sees us in the same figure as we see the full Moon. 'Tis then, with the Inhabitants of the Moon, full Earth, if I may be permitted the expression. Afterward the Moon, which advances in her monthly Circle, disingages from under the Sun, and begins to shew us a little corner of her inlighten'd half; and that's the Crescent: and then likewise the parts of the Moon that are benighted begin not to see all the half of the Earth that is inlighten'd, and we are running from them.

explanations: The French "Il y a bien de l'erreur par tout" (There is much error everywhere) is rendered as "there's faults enough every where." The English uses a more common, slightly more colloquial phrasing with "faults enough," simplifying the somewhat more formal "bien de l'erreur" and making it more direct.

The French phrase "d'entreprendre d'y rien réformer," which in this negative context means "to undertake to reform anything there," uses a complex grammatical construction where "rien" takes on the meaning of "anything." The English translation "to attempt a Reformation" simplifies this intricate structure into a more direct and easily understood phrase, conveying the idea of "any act of reforming" more straightforwardly.

The French "Il y a donc toûjours une moitié, tant de la Terre que de la Lune, qui est éclairée du Soleil" (literally, "There is therefore always one half, as much of the Earth as of the Moon, which is illuminated by the Sun") is restructured into the more active "Then the Sun daily enlightens one half both of the Earth and the Moon." This change to an active voice with the agent (Sun) as the direct subject simplifies the sentence structure compared to the French existential "Il y a" followed by a relative clause with a passive verb construction.

The French "comme une Balle a moins de force & de vitesse après qu'elle a été donner contre une muraille qui l'a renvoyée d'un autre côté" (as a ball has less force and speed after it has hit against a wall which has sent it back another way) is translated as "as a Ball loses its force when reverberated from a Wall". This simplifies the original by omitting the mention of "vitesse" (speed) and by condensing the lengthy descriptive clause about the ball's impact and rebound into the more concise phrase "when reverberated from a Wall," streamlining the sentence and reducing descriptive detail.

The French "c'est qu'elle est entre le Soleil & nous" (it is that she is between the Sun and us) is rendered as "she is then between the Sun and us." The English version simplifies the French "c'est que" construction, which is often used for emphasis or explanation, by transforming it into a more direct declarative statement, thus streamlining the sentence for an English reader.

The French idiomatic expression "Nous n'avons garde de voir cette moitié" (meaning "We are far from seeing" or "We certainly do not see that half") is translated as "We do not look to see that half". This simplifies the original by replacing a specific French idiom with a more straightforward English verb phrase using common vocabulary, potentially making it more accessible, though some of the idiom's nuance (implying impossibility or lack of opportunity rather than lack of trying) might be altered.

The French phrase "& nous sommes en Décours pour elles" (meaning "and we are in a waning phase for them," applying the lunar term 'décours' to Earth as seen from the Moon) is translated as "and we are running from them." This simplifies the original by replacing a specific astronomical term used metaphorically ("en Décours" - waning) with a more common, dynamic, and arguably more easily visualized action ("running from them"). This change increases accessibility through everyday vocabulary but sacrifices the precision and the continuity of the astronomical metaphor of Earth having phases.

chunks.sourceHtml: P027: Il n'en faut pas davantage, dit brusquement la Marquise, je saurai tout le reste quand il me plaira, je n'ai qu'à y penser un moment, & qu'à promener la Lune sur son Cercle d'un mois. Je vois en gennral que dans la Lune ils ont un mois à rebours du nôtre, & je gage que quand nous avons pleine Lune, c'est que toute la moitié lumineuse de la Lune est tournée vers toute la moitié obscure de la Terre; qu'alors ils ne nous voyent point du tout, & qu'ils comtent Nouvelle Terre. Je ne voudrois pas qu'il me fût reproché de m'être fait expliquer tout au long une chose si aisée. Mais les Eclipses, comment vont-elles? Il ne tient qu'à vous de le deviner, répondis-je. Quand la Lune est Nouvelle, qu'elle est entre le Soleil & nous, & que toute sa moitié obscure est tournée vers nous qui avons le jour, vous voyez bien que l'ombre de cette moitié obscure se jette vers nous. Si la Lune est justement sous le Soleil, cette ombre nous le cache, & en même temps noircit une partie de cette moitié lumineuse de la Terre qui etoit vûë par la moitié obscure de la Lune. Voilà donc une Eclipse de Soleil pour nous pendant notre jour, & une Eclipse de Terre pour la Lune pendant sa nuit. Lors que la Lune est pleine, la Terre est entre elle & le Soleil, & toute la moitié obscure de la Terre est tournée vers toute la moitié lumineuse de la Lune. L'ombre de la Terre se jette donc vers la Lune; si elle tombe sur le Corps de la Lune, elle noircit cette moitié lumineuse que nous voyons, & à cette moitié lumineuse qui avoit le jour, elle luy dérobe le Soleil. Voilà donc une Eclipse de Lune pour nous pendant notre nuit, & une Eclipse de Soleil pour la Lune pendant le jour dont elle joüissait. Ce qui fait qu'il n'arrive pas des Eclipses toutes les fois que la Lune est entre le Soleil & la Terre, ou la Terre entre le Soleil & la Lune, c'est que souvent ces trois Corps ne sont pas tres exactement rangez en ligne droite, & que par consequent celuy qui devroit faire l'Eclipse, jette son ombre un peu à côté de celuy qui en devroit être couvert.
chunks.manualHtml: P022: 'Tis enough, said the Marchioness briskly, I shall know all the rest when I please, I need but think on it a moment and walk the Moon about her monthly Circuit. I see in general that in the Moon they have a month reverse to ours, and I'le hold a Wager, that when 'tis full Moon with us, 'tis the inlighten'd half of the Moon turn'd towards the obscure part of the Earth, and 'tis then they see us not at all, and count it New Earth. I would not be reproch'd to have requir'd so minute an explication of a thing so easie. But pray how happen the Ecclipses? That, said I, belongs to you to judge. When 'tis New Moon, that she is between us and the Sun, and that all her obscure part is turn'd towards us in our day time; you see well that the Shadow of that obscure half is cast towards us. If the Moon be directly under the Sun, that Shadow hides him from us, and at the same time darkens all that luminous part of the Earth that was seen by the obscure part of the Moon. See there an Eclipse of the Sun for us in our day time, and an Eclipse of the Earth for the Moon in their night. When the Moon is full the Earth is between her and the Sun, and all the obscure half of the Earth is turn'd towards the inlighten'd half of the Moon; The Shadow of the Earth is then cast towards the Moon, and if it fall upon the body of the Moon it darkens that luminous half waich we saw, and hides the Sun from that luminous half in the Moon where it was day. See there an Eclipse of the Moon for us in our night, and an Eclipse of the Sun for the Moon in her day The reason why Eclipses do not happen every time that the Moon is between the Sun and the Earth, or the Earth between the Sun and the Moon, is because those three bodies are not always in a right line one to the other, and by consequence that Body that ought to make the Eclipse casts its Shadow a little on one side of that which should be obscured by it.

explanations: The French phrase "Il n'en faut pas davantage" (literally "one doesn't need more of it," meaning "that's enough" or "no more is needed") is simplified to the more direct, concise, and common English phrase "'Tis enough." This reduces formality and idiomatic complexity, making the dialogue flow more briskly.

The French reflexive causative construction "m'être fait expliquer tout au long" (to have had explained to me at length) found within the larger clause is simplified. The English "to have requir'd so minute an explication" shifts the voice ("requir'd") and employs a more straightforward structure, avoiding the complexity of the French causative form and also replacing "tout au long" (at length) with vocabulary describing the explanation itself.

The idiomatic French question "comment vont-elles?" (literally "how do they go?"), used here to inquire about the nature or workings of eclipses, is simplified by using the more direct verb "happen." This makes the query about the mechanism of eclipses more explicit and less figurative.

The French clause "Il ne tient qu'à vous de le deviner" (It is up to you to guess it / It depends only on you to guess it) is simplified. The idiom "Il ne tient qu'à vous" is replaced by the more direct assignment of role "belongs to you," and "deviner" (to guess/divine) is rendered as "to judge," potentially making the expected action of deduction clearer to the reader.

The French relative clause "qui avons le jour" (who have the day), modifying "nous" (us), is simplified to the more concise prepositional phrase "in our day time." This reduces structural complexity by replacing a subordinate clause with a simpler, common grammatical structure.

The French phrase "Voilà donc" (So, there is... / And so, you see...) includes the explicit logical connector "donc" (so, therefore). The English translation "See there" omits a direct equivalent of "donc," simplifying the phrase by making it more directly presentational and reducing the explicit marking of logical consequence.

The French sentence structure, featuring a fronted indirect object phrase ("à cette moitié lumineuse qui avoit le jour") and using the somewhat literary verb "dérobe" (steals/snatches away), is simplified. The English translation uses a more standard subject-verb-object sentence order ("hides the Sun from...") and the more common, less figurative verb "hides," making the expression more direct and its structure easier to follow.

The French phrase "Voilà donc," which includes the explicit logical connector "donc" (so, therefore), is simplified to "See there." The omission of an equivalent for "donc" makes the statement more directly presentational, reducing the explicit marking of logical consequence, similar to a previous instance.

The French descriptive phrase "pendant le jour dont elle joüissait" (during the day which it was enjoying/of which it had the benefit), which includes a relative clause, is significantly simplified and shortened to "in her day." This reduces both sentence complexity and textual density by replacing the clause with a concise possessive phrase.

The French explanatory structure "Ce qui fait que X, c'est que Y" (Literally: "That which makes it that X, it is that Y") is rephrased into the more direct English construction "The reason why X is because Y." This simplifies the original cataphoric French structure by making the concept of "reason" explicit at the beginning of the clause, potentially enhancing readability for an English audience.

The French pronoun "celuy qui" (the one who/that which) is made more explicit in English as "that Body that." The addition of the noun "Body" clarifies the referent, reducing potential ambiguity and simplifying comprehension by making the agent more concrete rather than relying solely on a pronoun.

chunks.sourceHtml: P028: Je suis fort étonnée, dit la Marquise, qu'il y ait si peu de mystere aux Eclipses, & que tout le monde n'en devine pas la cause. Ah! vraiment, répondis-je, il y a bien des Peuples qui de la maniere dont ils s'y prennent, ne la devineroient encore de longtemps. Dans toutes les Indes Orientales, on croit que quand le Soleil & la Lune s'éclipsent, c'est qu'un certain Demon qui a les Griffes fort noires, les étend sur ces Astres dont il veut se saisir; & vous voyez pendant ce temps-là les Rivières couvertes de Têtes d'Indiens qui se sont mis dans l'eau jusqu'au cou, parce que c'est une situation tres propre à obtenir du Soleil & de la Lune qu'ils se défendent bien contre le Demon. En Amérique, on etoit persuadé que le Soleil & la Lune etoient fâchéz quand ils s'éclipsoient, & Dieu sait ce qu'on ne faisoit pas pour se raccommoder avec eux. Mais les Grecs qui etoient si raffinez, n'ont-ils pas creu long-temps que la Lune étoit ensorcelée, & que des Magiciennes la faisoient descendre du Ciel pour jeter sur les Herbes une certaine écume malfaisante? Mais nous, n'eûmes-nous pas belle peur il n'y guere plus de trente ans, à une certaine Eclipse de Soleil, qui arriva? Une infinité de Gens ne se tinrent-ils pas enfermez dans des caves, & les Philosophes qui écrivent pour nous rassurer, n'écrivirent ils pas en vain?
chunks.manualHtml: P023: I am very much astonished, said the Marchioness, that there should be so little Mystery in Eclipses, and yet all the World so ignorant of their Causes. Ah! said I, there are enough in the World, that as they go to work, will never understand them. The East Indians believe that when the Sun and Moon are in Eclipse, it is a certain Demon that with his black Paws stretch'd out towards those Stars, endeavours to lay hold on them, and you shall see at that time the Rivers cover'd with Heads of Indians, who plunge themselves up to the neck in Water, as the most devout posture, in their opinion, to prevail with the Sun and Moon to protect them from the Paws of the Demon. The Americans think the Sun and Moon are angry with them when they are eclips'd, and God knows what they do not, to reconcile themselves with them. The Greeks, who were so refin'd, did they not believe a long while that the Moon was then inchanted, and that she was brought down from Heaven by Magicians, to cast a malignant froth upon Herbs? And we our selves were we not very fairly frighten'd at an Eclipse of the Sun not above thirty years since? When an infinite number of people shut themselves up in Caves, and the Philosophers that imploy'd their Pens to incourage us, writ in vain.
