explanations: The Marquise's entire speech segment is a single question in the French original, as indicated by the final question mark. The English translation renders this as a declarative statement, simplifying the overall sentence mood from interrogative to assertive, which makes the tone more direct.

The French uses the subjunctive mood ("foient") in this concessive clause. The English translation simplifies this by using the indicative mood ("are"), which is structurally simpler and more common in English for this type of construction.

The French phrase "pendant ces nuits?" (during these nights?) uses the specific demonstrative "ces" (these) and is part of a larger question. The English "the nights of another." omits the specific demonstrative, generalizing the reference, and is part of a declarative statement, thus simplifying the specificity and interrogative aspect of the original phrase.

The French phrase "pour avoir le malheur d'être asservies" (for having the misfortune of being subjected) is simplified to "for being subjected." The explicit reference to "le malheur" (the misfortune) is omitted, reducing lexical richness and making the expression more concise.

The French conditional "auroient ... sujet de craindre" (would have ... reason to fear) is simplified to the present indicative "have ... cause to fear." This change makes the assertion more direct and factual, simplifying the more nuanced conditional mood of the original.

The French "C'est peut-être là aussi la frayeur qu'ils ont" (It is perhaps there also the fear that they have) is simplified by condensing "là aussi" (there also / in that also) and restructuring to "That is, possibly, ... the fear they have", resulting in more direct phrasing.

The French "& qu'il faut bien remplacer par quelque autre sottise?" (and which must indeed be replaced by some other foolishness?) is simplified. The abstract "il faut bien remplacer" (it is necessary to replace) is rendered by the more concrete and idiomatic English phrase "but must pay for it," using more common vocabulary to express the idea of a necessary trade-off.

The impersonal French construction "Il le faut de necessité absolue" (It is necessary by absolute necessity) is simplified to the more direct demonstrative construction "That is of absolute necessity," making the sentence onset structurally simpler.

The French idiomatic expression "n'avoit garde de craindre" (took care not to fear / was far from fearing) is simplified to the direct negation "he fear'd not." This replaces a more nuanced idiom with a straightforward statement, enhancing readability.

The French "croiriez-vous bien" (would you indeed believe / would you really believe) is simplified to "would you believe." The emphatic adverb "bien" (indeed, really) is omitted, reducing the emphasis and making the question more direct and less lexically dense.

The French sentence segment "Si en sortant de son logis la premiere personne qu'il rencontroit êtoit une Vieille" (If, upon leaving his lodging, the first person he met was an Old Woman) uses a conditional clause containing a participial phrase ("en sortant"). The English translation simplifies this structure by creating a temporal clause "When he went..." followed by a conditional clause "if the first person...", making the syntax less dense.

The French phrase "sans oser commencer la moindre chose" (without daring to begin the slightest thing), a subordinate prepositional phrase with an infinitive, is simplified into a coordinate clause "and not dare to take in hand the least matter." This change from subordination to coordination makes the sentence structure more linear and easier to follow.

chunks.sourceHtml: P072: Il ne seroit pas juste, reprit- elle, après que cet homme-là n'a pû se delivrer impunément de la, que les Habitans de cette Lune de Jupiter, dont nous parlions, en fussent quittes à meilleur marché. Nous ne leur ferons pas de quartier, ils subiront la Loy commune, & donneront dans quelque autre erreur, mais comme je ne me pique pas de la pouvoir deviner, éclaircissez-moy, je vous prie, une autre difficulté qui m'occupe depuis quelques moments. Si la Terre est si petite à l'égard de Jupiter, Jupiter nous voit-il? Je crains que nous ne luy soyons inconnus.
chunks.manualHtml: P066: It would not be just, said she, since that Man could not deliver himself from the fear of Eclipses, without paying for it by some folly, that the Inhabitants of that Moon of Iupiter, which we speak of, should free themselves with less trouble, we'l give them no Quarter, they shall undergo the Common Law, and fall into some other Errour, but-how, I trouble not my head to guess. Therfore pray explain to me another difficulty has possess'd me within this little while, if the Earth be so little in respect of Iupiter, doth Iupiter see us? I fear we are unknown to him.
chunks.aiHtml: P066: It would not be just, said she, since that Man could not deliver himself from the fear of Eclipses, without paying for it by some folly, that the Inhabitants of that Moon of Iupiter, which we speak of, should free themselves with less trouble, we'l give them no Quarter, they shall undergo the Common Law, and fall into some other Errour, but-how, I trouble not my head to guess. Therfore pray explain to me another difficulty has possess'd me within this little while, if the Earth be so little in respect of Iupiter, doth Iupiter see us? I fear we are unknown to him.
explanations: The French text uses the anaphoric 'de la' to refer to a previously discussed concept (likely escaping one superstition only to fall into another). The English translation simplifies by explicating this reference as 'from the fear of Eclipses, without paying for it by some folly,' making the meaning immediately accessible and reducing the reader's cognitive load. Additionally, the idiomatic French 'en fussent quittes à meilleur marché' (to get away with it more cheaply/at a better bargain) is rendered as the simpler and more direct 'should free themselves with less trouble,' using more common vocabulary.

The French phrase 'je ne me pique pas de la pouvoir deviner,' which implies a certain sophisticated detachment ('I don't pride myself on being able to guess it' or 'I don't make a point of it'), is simplified in English to the more colloquial, direct, and less formal 'I trouble not my head to guess.' This involves a shift to more common vocabulary and a simpler idiomatic construction.

The French sentence employs the subjunctive mood ('soyons') along with the 'ne explétif' after 'craindre que' (to fear that), a grammatical construction that can add complexity. The English translation simplifies this structure by using the indicative mood ('are'), resulting in a more direct and grammatically simpler statement for the English reader.

chunks.sourceHtml: P073: De bonne foy, je croy que cela est, répondis-je. Il faudroit qu'il vît la Terre quatre-vingt-dix fois plus petite que nous ne le voyons. C'est trop peu, il ne la voit point. Voicy seulement ce que nous pouvons croire de meilleur pour nous. Il y aura dans Jupiter des Astronomes, qui aprés avoir bien pris de la peine à composer des Lunettes excellentes, aprés avoir choisy les plus belles Nuits pour observer, auront enfin découvert dans les Cieux une petite Planete qu'ils n'avoient jamais veüe. D'abord le Journal des Savants de ce Pays-là en parle; le Peuple de Jupiter, ou n'en entend point parler, ou n'en fait que rire. Les Philosophes dont cela détruit les opinions, forment le dessein de n'en rien croire, il n'y a que les Gens tres raisonnables qui en veulent bien douter. On observe encore, on revoit la petite Planete, on s'assure bien que ce n'est point une vision; on commence même à soupçonner qu'elle a un mouvement autour du Soleil; on trouve au bout de mille observations, que ce mouvement est d'une année; & enfin, grâce à toutes les peines que se donnent les Savats, on sait dans Jupiter que notre Terre est un Monde. Les Lurieux vont la voir au bout d'une Lunette, & la veüe à peine peut-elle encore l'attraper.
chunks.manualHtml: P067: Truly, says I, I believe that, he must needs see the Earth ninety times less than we see him, that's too little, he sees it not all: But here's that which we may better believe for our advantage, there may be Astronomers in Iupiter, who having taken pains to make excellent Telescopes, and choosing the fairest nights for Observation, may at last have discover'd in the Heavens a little Planet which they never saw before, presently the Iournal des Scivans of that Country speaks of it; the people of Iupiter either hear nothing of it, or only laugh at it. The Philosophers, whose Opinions it destroys, are resolved not to believe it; none but the most reasonable doubt of it Observations are repeated, and the little Planet is reviewed; people are certain that 'tis no Vision, and begin to suspect that it moves about the Sun, after a thousand Observations 'tis discover'd that that motion is annual, and at last, thanks to the pains and studies of the Virtuoso's, 'tis known in Iupiter that our Earth is a World, the curious run to gaze on it with their Telescopes, and scarcely is it discernable.

explanations: The French subjunctive construction 'Il faudroit qu'il vît' (It would be necessary that he saw / He would have to see) is simplified to the more direct modal construction 'he must needs see', reducing grammatical complexity.

The French constructions using pronominal adverbs and specific negative/restrictive forms, 'n'en entend point parler' (doesn't hear of it at all) and 'n'en fait que rire' (does nothing but laugh at it), are simplified to 'hear nothing of it' and 'only laugh at it,' which are more direct and use simpler syntactic structures.

The French periphrastic phrase 'forment le dessein de n'en rien croire' (literally 'form the plan of believing nothing of it') is simplified to the more concise 'are resolved not to believe it.' This reduces the complexity of 'forment le dessein de' (form the plan to) to the simpler 'are resolved'.

The French phrase 'qui en veulent bien douter' (who are quite willing/ready to doubt it) is simplified to 'doubt of it'. This omits the nuance of active willingness or readiness conveyed by the idiomatic 'veulent bien', thereby reducing expressive detail.

The reflexive French phrase 'on s'assure bien que' (one makes oneself well-assured that / one makes sure that), which implies a process of verification, is simplified to the more direct statement of state 'people are certain that,' reducing the complexity of the verb phrase.

The French 'on commence même à soupçonner' (one even begins to suspect) includes the adverb 'même' (even), which adds a layer of emphasis or marks a progression. Its omission in the English 'and begin to suspect' simplifies the statement by removing this nuance.

The French 'la veüe à peine peut-elle encore l'attraper' (sight/the view can scarcely still catch it), which uses a more literary construction personifying 'sight' and employing the metaphorical verb 'attraper' (to catch), is simplified to the more direct and impersonal statement 'scarcely is it discernable.' This changes the sentence structure, active agent, and verb choice to a more common and less figurative form, also omitting 'encore' (still/yet).

chunks.sourceHtml: P074: Si ce n'êtoit, dit la Marquise, qu'il n'est point trop agreable de savoir qu'on ne nous peut découvrir de dedans Jupiter qu'avec des Lunettes d'approche, je me représenterois avec plaisir ces Lunettes de Jupiter dressées vers nous, comme les nôtres le sont vers luy, & cette curiosité mutuelle avec laquelle les Planetes s'entre-considèrent & demandent l'une de l'autre, Quel monde est-ce là? Quelles gens l'habitent?
chunks.manualHtml: P068: If it were not, said the Marchioness, that it is not very satisfactory to know that from Iupiter they cannot discover us without a Telescope. I should take pleasure in representing to my self those Telescopes of Iupiter planted toward us as ours are to behold him, and that mutual curiosity of the two Planets in considering one another, and asking What World is this? What People inhabit here?
chunks.aiHtml: P068: If it were not, said the Marchioness, that it is not very satisfactory to know that from Iupiter they cannot discover us without a Telescope. I should take pleasure in representing to my self those Telescopes of Iupiter planted toward us as ours are to behold him, and that mutual curiosity of the two Planets in considering one another, and asking What World is this? What People inhabit here?
explanations: This segment shows simplification in two aspects. Firstly, the French "point trop agreable" (literally "not too pleasant," implying "rather unpleasant") is rendered as "not very satisfactory." This lexical choice shifts the nuance from a direct emotional quality ("pleasantness") to a more detached assessment ("satisfactoriness"), potentially simplifying the original's specific affective tone for the reader. Secondly, the phrase "de dedans Jupiter" (from within Jupiter) is simplified to "from Iupiter," omitting the word "dedans" (within). This reduction in spatial specificity makes the expression less dense and more direct.

The French phrase "comme les nôtres le sont vers luy" (literally, "as ours are so towards him," implying they are pointed/directed towards him) is concise and relies on the context of the previously mentioned action of aiming telescopes. The English translation "as ours are to behold him" simplifies this by making the implied purpose of the telescopes explicit with the addition of "to behold him." This reduces the inferential load on the reader, enhancing readability.

The French "les Planetes" (the Planets) within the clause "avec laquelle les Planetes s'entre-considèrent" (with which the Planets consider each other) is translated as "the two Planets" in the English phrase "of the two Planets in considering one another." This specification (referring contextually to Earth and Jupiter) makes the interaction clearer and less ambiguous than the potentially more general French term, thereby simplifying comprehension. The structural shift from a relative clause to a prepositional phrase with a gerund also tends to create a more direct construction in English.

chunks.sourceHtml: P075: Cela ne va pas si vite que vous pensez, répliquay-je. Quand on verroit nôtre Terre de dedans Jupiter, quand on l'y connoîtroit, nôtre Terre ce n'est pas nous; on n'a pas le moindre soupçon qu'elle puisse être habitée. Si quelqu'un vient à se l'imaginer, Dieu sait comme tout Jupiter se moque de luy. Peut-être même sommes-nous cause qu'on y a fait le procés à des Philosophes qui ont voulu soûtenir que nous êtions. Cependant je croirois plus volontiers que les Habitans de Jupiter sont assez occupez à faire des découvertes sur leur Planete, pour ne songer point du tout à nous. Elle est si grande, que s'ils navigent, assurément leurs Christophe Colombs ne sauroient manquer d'employ. Il faut que les Peuples de ce Monde-là ne connoissent pas seulement de réputation la centiéme partie des autres Peuples, au lieu que dans Mercure, qui est fort petit, ils sont tous voisins les uns des autres, ils vivent familierement ensemble, & ne comptent que pour une promenade de faire le tour de leur Monde. Si on ne nous voit point dans Jupiter, vous jugez bien qu'on y voit encore moins Venus & Mercure, qui sont des Mondes, & plus petits, & plus éloignez de luy. En récompense ses Habitans voyent Mars, & leurs quatre Lunes, & Saturne avec les siennes. Voilà assez de Planetes pour embarrasser ceux d'entre eux qui sont Astronomes; la Nature a eu la bonté de leur cacher ce qui en reste dans l'Univers.
chunks.manualHtml: P069: Hold, said I, that's not so soon done as you imagine: should the Inhabitants of Iupiter see our Earth, and know it, yet our Earth is not our selves; there would not be the least suspicion that 'tis inhabited: and should any one chance to entertain such a thought, God knows how the whole World of Iupiter would mock him. Nay possibly we have already been the cause of arraigning some of their Philosophers for holding that we have a Being in Nature. In the mean time I rather believe, that the Inhabitants of Iupiter have imployment enough in making discoveries in their own Planet, without ever dreaming of us; it is so big, that if they have the Art of Navigation, their Christopher Columba's have most certainly imployment enough. It must needs be that the people of that World do not know the hundredth part of it; whereas in Mercury, which is very little, they are all Neighbours, live very familiarly together, and count it but a Walk, to make a turn about their World. If they do not see us from Iupiter, you will easily judge that the people of that Planet do much less see Venus and Mercury, which are both lesser Worlds, and more distant from him. But to make amends, his inhabitants see Mars, and their own four Moons, and Saturn with his. These are Planets enough to perplex their Astronomers, and Nature has been so kind to conceal the rest of the Universe from them.
chunks.aiHtml: P069: Hold, said I, that's not so soon done as you imagine: should the Inhabitants of Iupiter see our Earth, and know it, yet our Earth is not our selves; there would not be the least suspicion that 'tis inhabited: and should any one chance to entertain such a thought, God knows how the whole World of Iupiter would mock him. Nay possibly we have already been the cause of arraigning some of their Philosophers for holding that we have a Being in Nature. In the mean time I rather believe, that the Inhabitants of Iupiter have imployment enough in making discoveries in their own Planet, without ever dreaming of us; it is so big, that if they have the Art of Navigation, their Christopher Columba's have most certainly imployment enough. It must needs be that the people of that World do not know the hundredth part of it; whereas in Mercury, which is very little, they are all Neighbours, live very familiarly together, and count it but a Walk, to make a turn about their World. If they do not see us from Iupiter, you will easily judge that the people of that Planet do much less see Venus and Mercury, which are both lesser Worlds, and more distant from him. But to make amends, his inhabitants see Mars, and their own four Moons, and Saturn with his. These are Planets enough to perplex their Astronomers, and Nature has been so kind to conceal the rest of the Universe from them.
explanations: The French "je croirois plus volontiers" uses the conditional mood ("croirois" - I would believe) and the adverbial phrase "plus volontiers" (more willingly/readily). The English "I rather believe" simplifies this by using the indicative mood and the common expression "rather believe," making the assertion more direct and slightly reducing the formality and nuanced conditionality of the original.

The French "ne sauroient manquer d'employ" (lit. "would not know how to be without employment") is an idiomatic and somewhat complex modal construction indicating the certainty of having employment. The English "have most certainly imployment enough" simplifies this by using the direct verb "have" emphatically modified by "most certainly," resulting in a more straightforward and less structurally intricate expression of this certainty.

The French "ne connoissent pas seulement de réputation" (do not even know by reputation) includes a specific qualifier about the nature or extent of (non-)knowledge. The English translation "do not know" omits the modifying phrase "seulement de réputation," simplifying the statement by removing this nuance and reducing informational detail for greater conciseness.

The French "ceux d'entre eux qui sont Astronomes" (literally, "those among them who are Astronomers") is a descriptive phrase involving a demonstrative pronoun, a prepositional phrase, and a relative clause. The English "their Astronomers" simplifies this structure significantly to a possessive pronoun and a noun, making the reference more concise and direct, thereby reducing phrasal complexity and length.

chunks.sourceHtml: P076: Quoy, dit la Marquise, vous comptez cela pour une grâce? Sans doute, répondis-je. Il y a dans tout ce grand Tourbillon seize Planetes. La Nature qui veut nous épargner la peine d'étudier tous leurs mouvemens, ne nous en montre que sept, n'est-ce pas là une assez grande faveur? Mais nous, qui n'en sentons pas le prix, nous faisons si bien que nous attrapons les neuf autres qui avoient êté cachées; aussi en sommes-nous punis par les grands travaux que l'Astronomie demande presentement.
chunks.manualHtml: P070: How, said the Marchioness, do you count that a kindness? Without doubt it is, said I, there are in all this great Vortex sixteen Planets. Nature, who would save us the trouble of studying all their motions, has let us see but seven of them, is not that a great kindness? But we, who know not how to value it, have taken a course to find out the other nine that were conceal'd, and are punish'd for our pains by the great labour that Astronomy at present requires.

explanations: The French "Sans doute" is a concise elliptical affirmation. The English translation "Without doubt it is" explicates the implied verb "it is", making the philosopher's agreement more explicit and potentially easier for the reader to process, thereby simplifying the comprehension of the terse French.

The French "une assez grande faveur" (a sufficiently/quite great favor) includes the nuancing adverb "assez." The English translation "a great kindness" omits this nuance, presenting a more direct and less qualified statement. This simplification reduces lexical complexity by removing a subtle degree of modification.

The French segment containing the idiomatic and somewhat vivid expression "nous faisons si bien que nous attrapons" (we manage so well that we catch/discover) is rendered with "have taken a course to find out." This simplifies by replacing the figurative use of "attraper" (to catch) with the more common and literal "find out," and by unpacking the idiomatic "faisons si bien que" (manage so well that) into a more analytical phrase "have taken a course to." This enhances readability by opting for more standard vocabulary and a less dense construction for the core action of discovering the planets.

The French segment begins with "aussi en sommes-nous punis" (thus/therefore we are punished for it). The English translation "and are punish'd for our pains" simplifies this by: 1) replacing the consequential conjunction "aussi" with the simpler coordinating conjunction "and," reducing the explicit logical complexity at the start of the clause, and 2) replacing the potentially ambiguous pronoun "en" with the explicit and idiomatic phrase "for our pains," clarifying the reason for punishment and easing comprehension. The remainder of the clause is translated more directly.

chunks.sourceHtml: P077: Je voy, reprit-elle, par ce nombre de seize Planetes qu'il faut que Saturne ait cinq Lunes. Il les a aussi, répliquay-je, & de ces cinq Lunes, il y en a deux bien fraîchement découvertes; mais il ya a quelque chose qui est encore bien plus remarquable. Comme son année est de trente des nôtres, & que par consequent il a des Pays, où une seule nuit dure quinze ans entiers, devinez ce que la Nature a inventé pour éclaires des nuits si affreuses. Elle ne s'est pas contentée de donner cinq Lunes à Saturne, elle a mis autour de luy un grand Cercle, ou un grand Anneau qui l'environne entierement, & qui êtant assez élevé pour être hors de l'ombre du Corps de cette Planete, refléchit perpetuellement la lumiere du Soleil dans les lieux qui ne le voyent point.
chunks.manualHtml: P071: I find, says she, by that number of sixteen Planets, that Saturn ought to have five Moons. He has so, says I, and of those five, two are but lately discovered; but there is a thing yet much more remarkable, one of his years being thirty of ours, and by consequence there being Countreys in him, whose night is of fifteen years continuance, guess you what Nature has invented to inlighten such terrible nights. She was not satisfy'd with bestowing five Moons upon Saturn, but she has also inclos'd him with a great Circle or Ring, which is high enough raised to be out of the Shadow of the Body of that Planet, and continually reflects the Light of the Sun upon those places that do not see him.

explanations: The French uses the impersonal construction 'il faut que' followed by the subjunctive mood ('ait'), which is a more complex grammatical structure. The English translation simplifies this to 'that Saturn ought to have', using a more direct modal verb phrase common in English, thus reducing grammatical complexity.

The French phrase 'bien fraîchement découvertes' (meaning 'very freshly/recently discovered') is translated as 'but lately discovered'. This simplification involves using the more common English idiom 'but lately' (equivalent to 'only recently') and omitting the intensifier 'bien' (very), resulting in more common vocabulary and a slight reduction in descriptive emphasis.

The French 'a mis autour de luy ... un grand Anneau qui l'environne entierement' (put around him... a great Ring which surrounds him entirely) uses a common verb ('mis' - put) followed by an explicit descriptive relative clause. The English translation uses the more specific verb 'inclos'd him with...', which incorporates the meaning of 'surrounds entirely'. This lexical choice simplifies the sentence by rendering the explicit relative clause 'qui l'environne entierement' redundant, thus shortening the description and reducing textual density.

chunks.sourceHtml: P078: En verité, dit la Marquise, de l'air d'une personne qui rentroit en elle-même avec étonnement, tout cela est d'un grand ordre; il paroît bien que la Nature a eu en veüe les besoins de quelques Etres vivans, & que la distribution des Lunes n'a pas êté faite au hazard. Il n'en est tombé en partage qu'aux Planetes éloignées du Soleil, à la Terre, à Jupiter, à Saturne, car ce n'êtoit pas la peine d'en donner à Vénus & à Mercure, qui ne reçoivent que trop de lumiere, dont les nuits sont fort courtes, & qui les comptent apparemment pour de plus grands bienfaits de la Nature que leurs jours mêmes. Mais attendez, il me semble que Mars, qui est encore plus éloigné du Soleil que la Terre, n'a point de Lune. On ne peut pas vous le dissimuler, répondis-je, il n'en a point, & il faut qu'il ait pour ses nuits des ressources que nous ne savons pas. Vous avez veu des Phosphores, de ces matières liquides ou seches, qui en recevant la lumiere du Soleil, s'en imbibent, & s'en penetrent, & ensuite jettent un assez grand éclat dans l'obscurité. Peut-être Mars a-t-il de grands Rochers fort élevés, qui sont des Phosphores naturels, & qui prennent pendant le jour une provision de lumière qu'ils rendent pendant la nuit. Vous ne sauriez rier que ce ne fût un Spectacle assez agreable, de voir tous ces Rochers s'allumer de toutes parts dé que le Soleil seroit couché, & faire sans aucun art des illuminations magnifiques. Vous savez encore qu'il y a en Amérique des Oiseaux qui sont si lumineux dans les tenebres, qu'on s'en peut servir pour lire. Que savons-nous si Mars n'a point un grand nombre de ces Oiseaux, qui dés que la nuit est venuë, se dispersent de tous côtés, & vont répandre un nouveau jour?
chunks.manualHtml:
P072: Seriously and truly, says the Marchioness, with an Air of one astonish'd, all this is a work of great Order, it is very visible that Nature had in her eye the Necessities of every living Being, and that the Distribution of Moons was not a thing done at random. There's none share in it but the Planets farthest distant from the Sun, viz. the Earth, Iupiter and Saturn; for it was not worth the while to give them to Venus and Mercury, who receive but too much Light, whose Nights are short, and which they esteem a much greater benefit of Nature than their Days.

P073: But stay, says she, methinks Mars, who is father remov'd from the Sun than the Earth is, has no Moon. It cannot be deny'd, said I, he has none, and therefore he must have some other refuge in his nights than we know of. You have seen those Phosphores, of either dry or liquid matter, which receiving the Light of the Sun, imbibe it, and diffusing it in the dark, give a considerable light. Perhaps Mars has great Rocks high rais'd, which are natural Phosphores, and which in the day time make a provision of Light, which they disburse in the night. You cannot deny that it would be a delightful spectacle to see all those Rocks lighted at Sunset, and make magnificent Illuminations without any Art. You know likewise that there are in America certain Birds so luminous, that they give light enough to read by in the dark. How do we know but Mars has a great many of those Birds, which at nightfall disperse themselves every where, and create a new day?

explanations: The French `qui rentroit en elle-même` (who was collecting herself/reflecting inwardly) adds a layer of introspective nuance to the astonishment. The English translation omits this, simplifying the description of the Marquise's reaction by reducing its psychological complexity.

The French `Il n'en est tombé en partage qu'aux` is a somewhat formal and indirect passive-like construction. The English `There's none share in it but` uses a more direct and common active-voice phrasing ("none share"), simplifying the sentence structure for easier comprehension.
The adverb "fort" (very), which intensifies "courtes" (short), is omitted. This reduces descriptive intensity and makes the phrase more concise, simplifying it by removing a modifier.

The adverb "apparemment" (apparently), indicating conjecture, and the emphatic "mêmes" (even/very) following "leurs jours" are omitted. These omissions make the assertion more direct and less nuanced, simplifying the original's qualified statement.

The French `On ne peut pas vous le dissimuler` (One cannot hide it from you) uses "dissimuler" (to conceal). The English `It cannot be deny'd,` simplifies this by using a more common verb ("deny") and a more direct, standard idiomatic expression, reducing lexical complexity and formal circumlocution.

The French uses two distinct verbs, `s'en imbibent` (soak it up) and `s'en pénètrent` (are permeated by it), to describe light absorption. The translation simplifies this by using only `imbibe it,` for the absorption process, omitting the nuance of the second verb `s'en pénètrent,` thereby reducing the descriptive density of the process.

The French `Vous ne sauriez nier que ce ne fût` (lit. "You would not know how to deny that it would be") is a complex modal construction involving the conditional of "savoir" and the subjunctive. The English `You cannot deny that it would be` simplifies this to a more direct and common modal expression, making the grammatical structure less intricate.

The French phrase `s'allumer de toutes parts` (to light up on all sides/everywhere) provides specific spatial detail. The English translation `lighted` omits the adverbial phrase `de toutes parts`, simplifying the visual imagery by reducing this descriptive element.

The French `dé que le Soleil seroit couché` (as soon as the sun would be set) is a subordinate temporal clause. The English translation simplifies this to the concise prepositional phrase `at Sunset,`, reducing clausal complexity and sentence length.

The French `dans les tenebres,` uses "tenebres" (darkness, gloom), a more literary and less common term. The English translation `in the dark.` uses a more common and straightforward vocabulary choice, simplifying the diction.

The French `dés que la nuit est venuë,` (as soon as night has come,) is a subordinate temporal clause. The English `at nightfall` simplifies this to a more concise adverbial phrase, reducing clausal complexity.

The French `vont répandre` (go to spread) uses the "aller + infinitive" construction and `répandre un nouveau jour` (to spread a new day) is somewhat poetic. The English `create a new day?` simplifies the verb phrase to a single, more direct verb ("create") and uses a slightly less figurative expression, making it more straightforward.

chunks.sourceHtml:
P079: Je ne me contente, reprit-elle, ny de vos Rochers, ni de vos Oiseaux. Cela ne laisseroit pas d'être joly, mais puis que la Nature a donné tant de Lunes à Saturne & à Jupiter, c'est une marque qu'il faut des Lunes. J'eusse êté bien-aise que tous les Mondes éloignez du Soleil en eussent eu, si Mars ne nous fût point venu faire une exception desagreable. Ah! vraiment, répliquay-je, si vous vous mêliez de Philosophie plus que vous ne faites, il faudroit bien que vous vous accoûtumassiez à voir des exceptions dans les meilleurs Sistêmes. Il y a toûjours quelque chose qui y convient le plus juste du monde, & puis quelque chose aussi qu'on y fait convenir comme on peut, ou qu'on laisse-là, si on desespere d'en pouvoir venir à bout. Usons-en de même pour Mars, puis qu'il ne nous est point favorable, & ne parlons point de luy. Nous serions bien étonnez, si nous êtions dans Saturne, de voir sur nos têtes pendant la nuit ce grand Anneau qui iroit en forme de demiy Cercle d'un bout à l'autre de l'Horizon, & qui nous renvoyant la lumiere du Soleil feroit l'effet d'une Lune continuë. Et ne mettrons-nous point d'Habitans dans ce grand Anneau, interrompit-elle en riant? Quoy que je sois d'humeur, répondis-je, à en envoyer par tout assez hardiment, je vous avoüe que je n'oserois en mettre là, cet Anneau me paroît une Habitation trop irregulière. Pour les cinq petites Lunes, on ne peut pas se dispenser de les peupler. Si cependant l'Anneau n'êtoit, comme quelques-uns le soupçonnent, qu'un Cercle de Lunes qui se suivissent de fort prés, & eussent un mouvement égal, & que les cinq petites Lunes fussent trois échappées de ce grand Cercle, que de Mondes dans le Tourbillon de Saturne! Quoy qu'il en soit, avec le secours même de l'Anneau, les Gens de Saturne sont assez misérables. Il leur donne la lumiere, mais quelle lumiere, dans l'éloignement où il est du Soleil! Le Soleil même n'est pour eux qu'une petite Etoile blanche & pâle, qui n'a qu'un éclat & une chaleur bien foible, & si vous les mettiez dans nos Pays les plus froids, dans le Groënland, ou dans la Laponie, vous les verriez suër à grosses gouttes & expirer de chaud.

P080: Vous me donnez une idée de Saturne qui me gele, dit la Marquise, au lieu que tan tôt vous m'échauffiez en me parlant de Mercure. Il faut bien, répliquay-je, que les deux Mondes qui sont aux extrémitez de ce grand Tourbillon, soient opposées en toutes choses.

P081: Ainsi, reprit-elle, on est bien sage dans Saturne, car vous m'avez dit que tout le monde êtoit fou dans Mercure. Si on n'est pas bien sage dans Saturne, repris- je, du moins, selon toutes les apparences, on y est bien flegmatique. Ce sont Gens qui ne savent ce que c'est que de rire, qui prennent toûjours un jour pour répondre à la moindre question qu'on leur fait, & qui eussent trouvé Caton d'Utique trop badin & trop folâtre..
chunks.manualHtml: P074: I am not satisfy'd, says she, neither with your Rocks nor your Birds; not but that it may be very pretty; but since Nature has given so many Moons to Saturn and Iupiter, 'tis a sign there is occasion for them. I should have been glad that all the Worlds far distant from the Sun had them likewise, but Mars I find makes a disagreeable exception. Ah! says I, if you look'd more into Philosophy than you do , you would accustom your self to find exceptions in the best Systems. There is ever something that agrees very well, and something that we make agree as well as we can, or else we let it alone, if we despair of succeeding well in it. Let us deal so with Mars: since he doth not favour us, let us e'en say no more of him. We should be sufficiently astonished if we were in Saturn, to see over our heads in the night that great Ring, which moving in form of a Semicircle from one end of the Horizon to the other, reflects the Light of the Sun, and performs the office of a perpetual Moon. And, says the Marchioness, laughing, must we not likewise have Inhabitants in that great Ring? Truly said I, however I may be bold enough to plant them every where else, I must confess, I dare not place any there, that Ring seems a habitation too irregular. But as for the five little Moons, I think we cannot well dispense with peopling them; if in the mean time that Ring be, as some suspect, no more than a circle of Moons that follow one another very close with an equal motion, and that the five little Moons are such as have made their escape from the great Circle, what an infinity of Worlds shall we have in that Vortex of Saturn? however it be, the people of Saturn, with all the help of that Ring, are miserable enough. It gives them light, but what sort of a light at that distance from the Sun? the Sun it self is to them but a small Star, pale and wan, and has only a little glittering and a feeble heat. Were they brought into the coldest of our Countrys, as Groenland or Lapland, you would see them melt and expire with heat. You give me, says the Marchioness, an Idea of Saturn that freezes me, as just now you heated me in your discourse of Mercury. It must needs be, says I, that two Worlds that are in the extermities of this great Vortex, should be opposite in all things.

explanations: The French "il faut des Lunes" (moons are necessary/needed) is a direct statement of necessity. The English "'tis a sign there is occasion for them" uses the softer, more common, and slightly less forceful phrase "there is occasion for them," simplifying the directness of "il faut."

The complex French past conditional subjunctive structure ("si Mars ne nous fût point venu faire une exception desagreable," meaning "if Mars had not come to make us a disagreeable exception") is simplified. The English restructures this as an adversative clause introduced by "but" and uses a simple present indicative observation ("Mars I find makes"), significantly reducing grammatical complexity and changing the conditional hypothetical nature to a direct assertion.
The French includes "vraiment" (truly/indeed), adding emphasis to the interjection and reply. Its omission in the English "Ah! says I" simplifies the expression by removing this emphatic element.

The French "il faudroit bien que vous vous accoûtumassiez" (it would really be necessary that you accustom yourself), a complex modal construction involving a conditional verb ("faudroit") governing a subjunctive mood ("vous accoûtumassiez"), is simplified to the more direct English modal phrase "you would accustom your self."

The idiomatic French superlative "convient le plus juste du monde" (fits as perfectly as possible/fits most precisely in the world) is simplified to the more common and less emphatic "agrees very well," reducing the original's intensity and idiomatic richness.

The French conditional "je n'oserois en mettre là" (I would not dare to put any there) is simplified to the present indicative "I dare not place any there." This change reduces the hypothetical nuance of the conditional, making the statement more direct and grammatically simpler.

The French sentence uses a series of imperfect subjunctive verbs ("n'êtoit," "se suivissent," "eussent," "fussent") to describe a complex hypothetical situation. The English translation simplifies this grammatical structure by primarily using present indicative ("follow," "are"), present subjunctive ("be"), and present perfect ("have made"). This shift away from the consistent use of imperfect subjunctives reduces grammatical complexity, particularly in the rendering of "qui se suivissent de fort prés, & eussent un mouvement égal" (who followed each other very closely, and had an equal motion) as "that follow one another very close with an equal motion," which uses an indicative verb and a prepositional phrase instead of two parallel subjunctive verbs.

The French "un éclat & une chaleur bien foible" describes both brightness/shine ("éclat") and heat ("chaleur") as "bien foible" (very feeble/weak). The translation "a little glittering and a feeble heat" simplifies "éclat bien foible" (very weak/feeble brightness) to "a little glittering." This uses a more common, arguably less intense, descriptive phrase for the "éclat," simplifying the original's adjectival force.

The French "suër à grosses gouttes" (to sweat profusely / sweat with large drops) provides a specific physiological detail. The English translation simplifies this to "melt." While "melt" is a vivid figurative expression for intense heat, it replaces the precise original imagery with a more general and common verb, thereby simplifying the descriptive content.

chunks.sourceHtml: P082: Il me vient une pensée, dit-elle. Tous les Habitans de Mercure sont vifs, tous ceux de Saturne sont lents. Parmy nous les uns sont vifs, les autres lents; cela ne viendroit-il point de ce que nôtre Terre étant justement au milieu des autres Mondes, nous participons des extrémitez? Il n'y a point pour les hommes de Caractère fixe & déterminé; les uns sont faits comme les Habitans de Mercure, les autres comme ceux de Saturne, & nous sommes un mélange de toutes les especes qui se trouvent dans les autres Planetes. J'aime assez cette idée, repris- je, nous formons un assemblage si bizarre, qu'on pourroit croire que nous serions ramassez de plusieurs Mondes différents. A ce compte, il est assez commode d'être icy, on y voit tous les autres Mondes en abregé.
chunks.manualHtml: P075: So then, says she, they must be wise in Saturn; for you told me, they are all fools in Mercury. If they are not wise in Saturn, said I, they are, at least in all appearance `very flegmatick: they are people that know not what it is to laugh, that require a whole day to answer to the least Question, and would look upon Cato of Vitica as a Buffoon or a Jack-pudding. I have a thought in my head, says she; all the Inhabitants of Mercury are lively, and all those of Saturn are dull; among us some are lively and some are dull, doth not this proceed from hence, that we being just in the middle between those other Worlds, participate of the extremities? There is no fixed and determinate Character for Man, some are fram'd like the Inhabitants of Mercury, others like those of Saturn, and we are a mixture of all species that are in the other Planets. I like that idea, said I, well enough, we make up so odd a kind of likeness, that it may be thought we are a Collection out of several different Worlds; and therefore 'tis convenient enough to be here, where we see all the other Worlds in compendium.

explanations: The French phrase "Il me vient une pensée" (literally "a thought comes to me") is concise and possesses a somewhat literary quality. The English translation "I have a thought in my head" employs more common, everyday vocabulary and a slightly more colloquial phrasing, simplifying the original's conciseness and literary touch by making it more direct and less formal.

The French word "lents" translates to "slow." The English translation uses "dull," which, while related, is a more common contrasting term to "lively" in everyday English. "Dull" implies slow-wittedness or a lack of vivacity, potentially simplifying "lents" by using a more broadly understood and evocative term that enhances the contrast for easier accessibility, possibly at the expense of the neutrality or precise meaning of "lents."

The French conditional passive voice in "nous serions ramassez" (we would be/have been gathered) conveys a hypothetical or speculative condition regarding humanity's composite nature. The English translation changes this to the simple present indicative "we are a Collection," which simplifies the grammatical structure by removing the conditional mood. This makes the assertion more direct and less nuanced, reducing the speculative quality of the original statement.

The French phrase "A ce compte," (literally "at this count," meaning "on that account" or "by that reckoning") serves as a somewhat formal or literary connective phrase. The English translation "and therefore" is a more common, straightforward, and simpler logical conjunction, streamlining the transitional expression and making the logical link more immediately obvious.

chunks.sourceHtml: P083: Du moins, reprit la Marquise, une commodité fort réelle qu'a nôtre Monde par sa situation, c'est qu'il n'est ny si chaud que celuy de Mercure ou de Venus, ny si froid que celuy de Jupiter ou de Saturne. De plus, nous sommes justement dans un endroit de la Terre où nous ne sentons l'excés ny du chaud ni du froid. En verité si un certain Philosophe rendoit grâce à la Nature d'être Homme, & non pas Bête, Grec, & non pas Barbare, moi je veux luy rendre grâce d'être sur la Planete la plus tempérée de l'Univers, & dans un des lieux les plus temperez de cette Planete. Si vous m'en croyez, Madame, répondis-je, vous luy rendrez grâce d'être jeune & non pas vieille; jeune & belle, & non pas jeune & laide; jeune & belle Françoise, & non pas jeune & belle Italienne. Voila bien d'autres sujets de reconnoissance que ceux que vous tirez de la situation de vôtre Tourbillon, ou de la température de vôtre Pays.
chunks.manualHtml: P076: At least, said the Marchioness, our World has one real convenience by the Scituation, that it is neither so hot as Mercury or Venus, nor so cold as Iupiter or Saturn; and moreover we are seated just in a part of the Earth where we find excess neither of Heat nor Cold. Seriously, if a certain Philosopher gave thanks to Nature for making him a Man and not a Beast, a Greek and not a Barbarian, I for my share give her thanks for placing me in the most temperate Planet of the Universe, and in the most temperate place of that Planet. Believe me, Madam, said I, you may give her thanks that you are young and not old, young and fair, and not young and ugly; a young and fair French-woman, and not a young and fair Italian: these are things to be acknowledg'd as advantages as well as those you receive by the Scituation of your Vortex and the Temperature of your Countrey.

explanations: The French construction 'une commodité... qu'a [sujet]..., c'est que [clause]' (a convenience... that [subject] has..., it is that [clause]) is a characteristic French structure used for emphasis. The English translation simplifies this into a more direct subject-verb-object structure ('our World has one real convenience') followed by a standard 'that' clause. This alteration streamlines the sentence flow and removes the emphatic but structurally more complex 'c'est que' construction. Additionally, the omission of the intensifier 'fort' (very) from 'fort réelle' (very real) to 'real convenience' represents a minor lexical simplification, making the statement more direct.

The French conditional phrase 'Si vous m'en croyez' (literally, 'If you believe me about it/in this') is simplified to the direct imperative 'Believe me.' This change reduces the phrase's length and syntactic complexity, making the philosopher's interjection more concise and assertive.

The French phrase 'Voila bien d'autres sujets de reconnoissance que ceux que vous tirez de...' is simplified by replacing the formal and abstract noun phrase 'sujets de reconnoissance' (subjects/reasons for gratitude) with the more explicit and common 'things to be acknowledg'd as advantages.' The verb 'tirez de' (draw/derive from) is replaced by the more common 'receive.' Furthermore, the comparative structure 'bien d'autres... que...' (many other... than...) is changed to the simpler additive conjunction 'as well as...', which reduces the comparative nuance and makes the relationship between the ideas easier to process.

chunks.sourceHtml: P084: Mon Dieu! répliqua-t-elle, laissez-moy avoir de la reconnaissance sur tout, jusque sur le Tourbillon où je suis placée. La mesure de bonheur qui nous a été donnée, est assez petite; il n'en faut rien perdre, & il est bon d'avoir pour les choses les plus communes, & les moins considérables, un goût qui les mette à profit. Si on ne vouloit que des plaisirs vifs, on en auroit peu, on les attendroit long-temps, & on les payeroit bien. Vous me promettez donc, répliquay-je, que si on vous proposoit de ces plaisirs vifs, vous vous souviendriez des Tourbillons & de moy, & que vous vous borneriez à nous? Ouy, répondit-elle, mais faites que la Philosophie me fournisse toûjours des plaisirs nouveaux. Du moins pour demain, répondis-je, j'espere qu'ils ne vous manqueront pas. J'ai des Etoiles fixes qui passent tout ce que vous avez vu jusqu'icy.
chunks.manualHtml: P077: Good God! said the Marchioness, let me acknowledge all, even to the Vortex where I am plac'd, the proportion of Happiness that has been measur'd out to us is very small, and we ought to be chary of it and lose none, and it is good to entertain such a relish and sense of even the most common and inconsiderable things, as may render them useful to us. If we desire only lively pleasures, we shall have few, stay long and pay dear for them. You will promise me then, said I, if I propose lively pleasures to you, you will remember me and my Vortices, and will be of our side. I will, said she, but you must provide that Philosophy still supply me with new pleasures. At least, said I, to morrow, I hope, you shall not fail of them. I have fixed Stars that will go beyond all that you have seen yet.

explanations: The French phrase "avoir de la reconnaissance sur tout" expresses a deep sense of gratitude or appreciation for everything. The translation "let me acknowledge all" simplifies this by using the more common and less semantically rich verb "acknowledge," reducing the original's emotional depth for greater directness and easier comprehension.

The French "Si on ne vouloit que" uses the impersonal pronoun "on" and the imperfect indicative "vouloit" (wanted/were to want), implying a more general or attenuated hypothetical condition. The English "If we desire only" simplifies this by using a personal pronoun "we" and the present indicative "desire," making the statement more direct and less nuanced in its temporal and modal aspects.

The French phrase "on les attendroit long-temps," meaning "one would wait for them for a long time," which includes an impersonal pronoun ("on") and a conditional verb ("attendroit"), is simplified to the very concise verb phrase "stay long." This significantly reduces the length and structural complexity of the original expression.

The French "si on vous proposoit," employing the impersonal pronoun "on" and the imperfect subjunctive "proposoit" (proposed/were to propose) to convey a hypothetical condition, is simplified to "if I propose." This change to a personal pronoun ("I") and the present indicative mood ("propose") makes the condition more direct, personal, and less grammatically complex.

The French "que vous vous borneriez à nous?" (that you would limit/content yourself with us?), which uses a conditional reflexive verb ("se borner à") to express a nuanced commitment, is simplified to "and will be of our side." The English phrase uses a simpler verb tense (future simple) and a common, more straightforward idiom, thereby reducing stylistic complexity and altering the original nuance from contentment/limitation to allegiance.

chunks.sourceHtml: P085: CINQUIEME SOIR. Que les étoiles fixes sont autant de Soleils, dont chacun éclaire un monde.
chunks.manualHtml: P078: THE Fifth Evening.
chunks.aiHtml: P078: THE Fifth Evening.
explanations: The English translation simplifies the original French heading. The French heading consists of two parts: 'CINQUIEME SOIR' (Fifth Evening) and a descriptive subtitle, 'Que les étoiles fixes sont autant de Soleils, dont chacun éclaire un monde' (That the fixed stars are so many Suns, each of which illuminates a world). The English translation renders 'CINQUIEME SOIR' as 'THE Fifth Evening' but completely omits the descriptive subtitle. This omission is an instance of language simplification as it significantly reduces the length and informational density of the heading, making it more concise but less thematically informative than the original French.

chunks.sourceHtml: P086:. La Marquise sentit une vraye impatience de savoir ce que les Etoiles Fixes deviendroient. Seront-elles habitées comme les Planetes me dit-elle? Ne le seront-elles pas? Enfin qu'en ferons-nous? Vous le devineriez peut-être, si vous en aviez bien envie, répondis-je. Les Etoiles Fixes ne sauroient être moins éloignées de la Terre que de quelques cinquante millions de lieuë, & si vous fâchiez un Astronome, il les mettroit encore plus loin. La distance du Soleil à la Planete la plus éloignée, n'est par rapport à la distance du Soleil ou de la Terre aux Etoiles Fixes, & on ne prend pas la peine de la compter. Leur lumière, comme vous voyez, est assez vive & assez éclatante. Si elles la recevoient du Soleil, il faudroit qu'elles la receussent déja bien foible aprés un trajet de cinquante millions de lieuë; il faudroit que par une reflexion qui l'affoibliroit encore beaucoup, elles nous la renvoyassent à cette même distance. Il seroit impossible qu'une lumière, qui auroit essuyé une reflexion, & fait deux fois cinquante millions de lieuë, eût cette force et cette vivacité qu'a celle des Etoiles Fixes. Les voilà donc lumineuses par elles-mêmes, & toutes, en un mot, autant de Soleils.
chunks.manualHtml: P079: THe Marchioness was sensibly impatient to know what would become of the fixed Stars. Shall they be inhabited, says she, as the Planets are, or shall they not? or what shall we do with them? Perhaps, said I, you might guess, if you would; the fixed Stars cannot be less distant from the Earth than some fifty millions of Leagues, and if you vex an Astronomer, he'l put them a great way further. The distance of the Sun from the most distant Planet, is nothing in comparison of the distance of the Sun or of the Earth from the fixed Stars, men do not take the pains to compute it. Their Light, as you see, is bright and lively enough. If they receive it from the Sun, they must needs receive it in a weak condition after a passage of fifty millions of Leagues, and they must return it to us through the same distance by a Reflection, that must yet much more impair the strength of it. It may seem impossible that a Light that is made by Reflection, and has travail'd twice fifty millions of Leagues, should retain that force and vivacity which we find in the fixed Stars. You see then they are all luminous in themselves, and in a word, are so many Suns.

explanations: The French phrase "si vous en aviez bien envie," expressing a strong or keen desire ("if you really felt like it/had a strong desire to"), is simplified to the more concise and less emphatic "if you would." This reduces vocabulary complexity and nuances of intensity for easier comprehension.

The French "ne sauroient être," an older and more literary conditional form (often of 'savoir' used for 'pouvoir', meaning 'could not be' or 'would not know how to be'), is simplified to the direct and common modal "cannot be," enhancing readability by using a more standard modern construction.

The French conditional "il les mettroit" (he would put them) is translated using the future simple with a colloquial contraction "he'l put them" (he will put them). This shift simplifies the verb tense and adopts a more informal, direct tone.

The French "n'est par rapport à" (literally "is not in relation to," implying insignificance when compared) is rendered as the more explicit and emphatic "is nothing in comparison of." This clarifies the meaning by using stronger, more direct vocabulary, thus simplifying the abstractness of the original.

The French "assez vive & assez éclatante" (quite lively/vivid & quite dazzling/brilliant) is simplified. The strong adjective "éclatante" (dazzling, brilliant) is rendered as the more common and less intense "bright." The structure with two separate "assez" (quite/rather) modifying each adjective is condensed to a single "enough" post-modifying the pair, simplifying the descriptive emphasis.

The French imperfect subjunctive "recevoient" (if they were to receive), used in a conditional clause, is simplified to the English simple present tense "receive" in the conditional "If they receive," making the grammatical structure more direct and common.

The impersonal French construction "il faudroit que" (it would be necessary that) followed by the imperfect subjunctive "qu'elles la receussent" (that they receive/should receive) is simplified to the more direct English modal expression "they must needs receive." This change replaces a complex subjunctive structure with a simpler active voice construction, enhancing readability.

The French "il faudroit que ... elles nous la renvoyassent" (it would be necessary that...they send it back, with "renvoyassent" as imperfect subjunctive) is simplified to "they must return it...". This replaces the impersonal modal construction using a subjunctive verb with a more direct active voice expression employing "must." The overall clausal structure involving the conditional relative "qui l'affoibliroit" is also streamlined.

The French phrase "qui auroit essuyé une reflexion" (which would have undergone/suffered a reflection), using a conditional perfect tense and the somewhat literary verb "essuyer," is simplified to "that is made by Reflection." This employs a simpler verb tense (present passive) and more direct, though arguably less nuanced, phrasing for easier comprehension.

The French imperfect subjunctive "eût" (had/possessed) in the clause "eût cette force et cette vivacité" is simplified to the more common English modal construction "should retain that force and vivacity," making the verb phrase more accessible to a general reader.

The French possessive relative clause "qu'a celle des Etoiles Fixes." (literally "that that [light] of the Fixed Stars has," with "celle" referring to "lumière") is simplified to "which we find in the fixed Stars." This rephrasing avoids a grammatically complex possessive construction with an implied antecedent, opting for a more general and structurally simpler observational clause.

The French presentative construction "Les voilà donc lumineuses" (So, there they are luminous / Behold them then luminous) is simplified by changing it to a more direct statement "You see then they are all luminous." This makes the inferential step more explicit ("You see then") and less reliant on an idiomatic French turn of phrase.

chunks.sourceHtml: P087: Ne me trompay-je point, s'écria la Marquise, ou si je vois où vous me voulez mener? M'allez-vous dire: Les Etoiles Fixes sont autant de Soleils, nôtre Soleil est le centre d'un Tourbillon qui tourne autour de luy, pourquoy chaque Etoile Fixe ne sera-t-elle pas aussi le centre d'un Tourbillon qui aura un mouvement autour d'elle? Notre Soleil a des Planetes qu'il éclaire, pourquoy chaque Etoile Fixe n'en aura-t-elle pas aussi qu'elle éclairera? Je n'ay à vous répondre, luy dis- je, que ce que répondit Phedre à Enone, C'est toi qui l'as nommé..
chunks.manualHtml: P080: I am not out of the way, cry'd the Marchioness, whether I go, or whether you lead me, you are going to tell me, That the fixed Stars are so many Suns, our Sun is the Center of a Vortex that turns about him, why should not every fixed Star be the Center of a Vortex that has likewise a motion about it? Our Sun has Planets which it inlightens, why should not every fixed Star have the like? I have no Answer, said I, but that of Phedra to Enone, 'Tis you have said it.
chunks.aiHtml: P080: I am not out of the way, cry'd the Marchioness, whether I go, or whether you lead me, you are going to tell me, That the fixed Stars are so many Suns, our Sun is the Center of a Vortex that turns about him, why should not every fixed Star be the Center of a Vortex that has likewise a motion about it? Our Sun has Planets which it inlightens, why should not every fixed Star have the like? I have no Answer, said I, but that of Phedra to Enone, 'Tis you have said it.
explanations: The original French 'Ne me trompay-je point...' expresses the Marquise's slight self-doubt or questioning ('Am I not mistaken...'). The English 'I am not out of the way' simplifies this by converting the nuanced interrogative into a more direct assertion of being correct. Furthermore, the French 'ou si je vois où vous me voulez mener?' ('or if I see where you want to lead me?'), which details her dawning realization of the philosopher's argument, is translated to the more general phrase 'whether I go, or whether you lead me,'. This simplification streamlines the Marquise's expression, making it more assertive and less psychologically nuanced by omitting the specific cognitive act of 'seeing' or understanding the argument's direction.

The French phrase 'qu'elle éclairera' (that it will illuminate) explicitly repeats the detail that each fixed star would illuminate its own planets, thereby creating a rhetorical parallel with the earlier statement about the Sun illuminating its planets. The English translation 'have the like?' simplifies this by using a general pronominal phrase ('the like'). This omits the specific repetition of the act of illumination, reducing the explicitness and rhetorical parallelism of the original. The simplification makes the sentence more concise but sacrifices some of the original's detail and stylistic richness.

chunks.sourceHtml: P088: Mais, reprit-elle, voila l'Univers si grand que je m'y perds, je ne sais plus où je suis, je ne suis plus rien. Quoy, tout sera divisé en Tourbillons jettez confusément les uns parmi les autres? Chaque Etoile sera le centre d'un Tourbillon peut-être aussi grand que celuy où nous sommes & Tout cet espace immense qui comprend notre Soleil & nos Planetes, ne sera qu'une petite parcelle de l'Univers? Autant d'espaces pareils que d'Etoiles Fixes?. Cela me confond, me trouble, m'épouvante. Et moi, répondis-je, cela me met à mon aise. Quand le ciel n'étoit que cette voûte bleuë, où les Etoiles êtoient cloüées, l'Univers me paroissoit petit & étroit, je m'y sentois comme oppressé; presentement qu'on a donné infiniment plus d'étenduë & de profondeur à cette voûte, en la partageant en mille & mille Tourbillons, il me semble que je respire avec plus de liberté, & que je suis dans un plus grand air, & assurement l'Univers a toute une autre magnificence. La Nature n'a rien épargné en le produisant, elle a fait une profusion des richesses qui est tout-à-fait digne d'elle. Rien n'est si beau à se representer que ce nombre prodigieux de Tourbillons, dont le milieu est occupé par un Soleil qui fait tourner des Planetes autour de luy. Les Habitans d'une Planete d'un de ces Tourbillons infinis voyent de tous côtés les centres lumineux des Tourbuillons dont ils sont environnez, mais ils n'ont garde d'en voir les Planetes qui n'ayant qu'une lumiere foible, empruntée de leur Soleil, ne la poussent point au delà de leur Monde..
chunks.manualHtml: P081: But, says she, why there's the Universe so big that I am lost in it, I know not where I am, I'm nothing. What, shall all be divided into Vortices confusedly thrown one among another? Shall evero Star be the Center of a Vortex as big perhaps as that wherein we are? Shall all the immense space that comprehends our Sun and our Planets be no more than a little Spot of the Universe? This confounds, perplexes and astonishes me. And, said I, for my share, I am wholly at ease. Were Heaven no more than that blue Vault where the Stars are nail'd, the Universe would seem small and narrow to me, and I should find my self straighten'd and oppress'd. But now that this Vault is of infinite more extent and profundity, in dividing it into a thousand thousand Vortices, methinks I breath with more liberty, and am in a more open Air; and most assuredly the Universe has wholly another Magnificence. Nature spar'd nothing in making it, but made a profusion of her Riches wholly worthy of her. Nothing can be represented so beautiful as that prodigious number of Vortices in the Center whereof is seated the Sun turning the Planets about him. The Inhabitants of a Planet of one of those infinite Vortices, see on all sides the luminous centers of those Vortices which surround them, but they see not the Planets, which having but a feeble light borrowed from their Sun, do not propagate it beyond their World.

explanations: The original French forms a single, complex interrogative sentence by linking two questions with "&". The translation simplifies this structure by separating it into two distinct, shorter questions, which improves readability and makes the line of reasoning easier to follow.

The French verb "m'épouvante" conveys a strong sense of fear or being appalled. The English translation uses "astonishes me," a more common verb that significantly lessens the emotional intensity to one of great surprise or wonder. This lexical choice simplifies the original's dramatic impact.

The French text uses a relative clause "qui fait tourner des Planetes" (which causes Planets to turn), explicitly stating the Sun's causative action. The English translation simplifies this to a more compact participial phrase "the Sun turning the Planets," reducing the grammatical complexity and making the description more direct.

The French "n'ont garde d'en voir" is an idiomatic expression meaning they are certain not to see, or are far from seeing. The translation "they see not the Planets" simplifies this by using a direct negation, losing the idiomatic nuance and stylistic richness of the original for a more straightforward statement.

The French "petite parcelle" (small part/fragment) is rendered as "little Spot." While "parcelle" can be understood, "spot" is a very common, everyday English word. This choice simplifies the vocabulary, potentially making the Marquise's expression feel slightly more informal and immediately accessible.

chunks.sourceHtml: P089: Vous m'offrez, dit-elle, une espece de Perspective si longue, que la veuë n'en peut attraper le bout. Je voy clairement les Habitans de la Terre, ensuite vous me faites voir ceux de la Lune & des autres Planetes de notre Tourbillon assez clairement à la verité, mais moins que ceux de la Terre; aprés eux viennent les Habitans des Planetes des autres Tourbillons. Je vous avoüe qu'ils sont tout-à-fait dans l'enfoncement, & que quelque effort que je fasse pour les voir, je ne les aperçois presque point. Et en effet ne sont-ils pas presque aneantis par l'expression dont vous êtes obligé de vous servir en parlant d'eux? Il faut que vous les appeliez, les Habitans d'une des Planetes, de l'un de ces Tourbillons infinis & Nous mêmes, à qui la même expression convient, avoüez que vous ne sauriez presque plus nous déméler au milieu de tant de Mondes. Pour moy, je commence à voir la Terre si effroyablement petite, que je ne croy pas avoir desormais d'empressement pour aucune chose. Assurément, si on a tant d'ardeur de s'agrandir, si on fait desseins sur desseins, si on se donne tant de peine, c'est que l'on ne connoît pas les Tourbillons.. Je pretends bien que ma paresse profite de mes nouvelles lumieres, & quand on me reprochera mon indolence, je répondrai: Ah! si vous saviez ce que c'est que les Etoiles Fixes! Il faut qu'Alexandre ne l'ait pas su, repliquay-je, car un certain Auteur qui tient que la Lune est habitée, dit fort serieusement qu'il n'êtoit pas possible qu'Aristote ne fût dans une opinion si raisonnable (comment une verité eût-elle échappé à Aristote?). mais qu'il n'en voulut jamais rien dire, de peur de déplaire, à Alexandre, qui eût êté au despoir de voir un Monde qu'il n'eût pas pu conquerir. A plus forte raison lui eût-on fait mystere des Tourbillons, des Etoiles Fixes, quand on les eût connus en ce temps-là; c'eût eté faire trop mal sa Cour que de luy en parler. Pour moy qui les connois, je suis bien fâché de ne pouvoir tirer d'utilité de la connoissance que j'en ay. Ils ne guerissent tout au plus, selon votre raisonnement, que de l'ambition & de l'inquietude, & je n'ay point ces maladies-là. Un peu de foiblesse pour ce qui est beau, voila mon mal, & je ne croy pas que les Tourbillons y puissent rien. Les autres Mondes vous rendent celuy-cy petit, mais ils ne vous gâtent point de beaux yeux, ou une belle bouche, cela vaut toûjours son prix en dépit de tous les Mondes possibles.
chunks.manualHtml: P082: You offer me, said she, a kind of Perspective so long, that my eye cannot reach the end of it. I clearly see the Inhabitants of the Earth, and afterward you shew me those of the Moon and the other Planets of our Vortex, truly clearly enough, but less than those of the Earth, and after them come the Inhabitants of the Planets of other Vortices. I protest to you they are wholly drown'd, and with all that I can do to see them, they are still almost wholly indiscernable. And in effect, are they not almost annihilated by the expression you are fain to make use of in speaking of them, you are fain to call them the Inhabitants of one of the Planets of one of those infinite Vortices. You must confess that you hardly know how to disingage us our selves, to whom the same expression agrees, from the midst of so many Worlds. For my share, I begin to see the Earth so fearfully little, that from hence forward I shall have no value for any thing in it. Certainly men are so earnest in the pursuit of Greatness, form Design upon Design, and turmoile themselves so much, only because they are ignorant of these Vortices. These new Lights I intend shall apologize for me; and when any blame me for an unactive negligence, my Answer shall be, Ah! if you did but know what the fixed Stars are! Alexander, says, I, certainly knew nothing of them; for a certain Author, who holds that the Moon is inhabited, says seriously, that it was not possible that Aristotle should not be of an opinion so reasonable (for how could a Truth escape Aristotle?) but that he would say nothing of it for fear of displeasing Alexander, who would have fallen into despair to have seen a World that he could not conquer. The truth is, should any one have made a Mystery of the Vortices and fixed Stars, had they been known in those days, it had been an ill Complement to have told him of them. I my self, that know them, am not a little concern'd that I can make no profit by the Knowledge. They at best, in your opinion, cure only an unquiet and ambitious mind, which I am not troubl'd with; a little foolish inclination for the thing that's fair, is all my malady, and I doubt the Vortices can do me little kindness in that. The other Worlds, you say, make this seem little to you, but yet they obscure not the Lustre of your Eyes, nor spoil that pretty Mouth, those have still the same value in spight of all the Worlds.

explanations: The French phrase "qu'ils sont tout-à-fait dans l'enfoncement" (that they are completely in the distant background/recess), describing the barely visible inhabitants, is translated as "they are wholly drown'd." While "enfoncement" is a precise term related to perspective and depth, "drown'd" (in the sense of being overwhelmed or lost to view) uses a more common, vivid, and arguably more easily grasped metaphor for the English reader of the period, simplifying the abstract spatial concept by making it more concrete and accessible.

The original French is a single, very long sentence with multiple complex clauses, linking the necessary way of referring to distant inhabitants ("Il faut que vous les appeliez...") and its implications for "ourselves" ("Nous mêmes... avoüez que..."). The English translation simplifies this complex syntactic structure by effectively breaking it down. The first part, "you are fain to call them...", directly states the expression (tying it to the preceding question about the expression used), and then a new main clause, "You must confess that...", introduces the consequence for "us." This division reduces the syntactic density of the original sentence, making the argument's progression easier to follow.

The French "Il faut qu'Alexandre ne l'ait pas su" uses a common but slightly indirect modal construction ("It must be that Alexander did not know it") to express strong probability or deduction. The English translation rephrases this as a more direct assertion "Alexander... certainly knew nothing of them", simplifying the grammatical complexity of the epistemic modality and making the statement more straightforward.

The French "c'eût eté faire trop mal sa Cour que de luy en parler" (it would have been too badly paying court to him to speak of them to him) is an idiomatic expression with specific cultural connotations of courtly behavior and diplomacy. The English translation "it had been an ill Complement to have told him of them" simplifies this by replacing the nuanced, culturally-specific idiom with a more general and universally understandable phrase for an inappropriate or impolitic remark. This makes the meaning more immediately accessible by using less culturally-bound vocabulary.

chunks.sourceHtml: P090: C'est une étrange chose que l'Amour, répondit-elle, en riant; il se sauve de tout, & il n'y a point de Systême qui luy puisse faire de mal. Mais aussi parlez- moi franchement, votre Systême est-il bien vray? Ne me déguisez rien, je vous garderay le secret. Il me semble qu'il n'est appuyé que sur une petite convenance bien legere. Une Etoile Fixe & lumineuse d'elle-même comme le Soleil, par consequent il faut qu'elle soit comme le Soleil, le centre & l'ame d'un Monde, & qu'elle ait ses Planetes qui tournent autour d'elle. Cela est-il d'une necessité bien absoluë? Ecoutez, Madame, répondis-je, puis que nous sommes en humeur de mêler toûjours des folies de galanterie à nos Discours les plus serieux, les raisonnemens de Mathematique sont faits comme l'Amour. Vous ne sauriez accorder si peu de chose à un Amant, que bien tôt aprés il ne faille luy en accorder davantage, & puis encore davantage, & à la fin cela va loin. De même accordez à un Mathematicien le moindre principe, il va vous en tirer une consequence, qu'il faudra que vous luy accordiez aussi, & de cette consequence encore une autre, & malgré vous-même il vous mene si loin, qu'à peine le pouvez vous croire. Ces deux sortes de Gens-là prennent toûjours plus qu'on ne leur donne. Vous convenez que quand deux choses sont semblables en tout ce qui me paroît, je les puis croire aussi semblables en ce qui ne me paroît point, s'il n'y a rien d'ailleurs qui m'en empêche. De là j'ay tiré que la Lune êtoit habitée, parce qu'elle ressemble à la Terre, les autres Planetes, parce qu'elles ressemblent à la Lune. Je trouve que les Etoiles Fixes ressemblent à nôtre Soleil, je leur attribuë tout ce qu'il a. Vous êtes engagée trop avant pour pouvoir reculer, il faut franchir le pas de bonne grâce. Mais, dit-elle, sur le pied de cette ressemblance que vous mettez entre les Etoiles Fixes & nôtre Soleil, il faut que les Gens d'un autre grand Tourbillon ne le voyent que comme une petite Etoile Fixe, qui se montre à eux seulement pendant leurs nuits.
chunks.manualHtml:
P083: This Love, said the Marchioness, laughing, is a strange thing, it has a Salvo for all things and there's no System can do it harm. But tell me pray, and tell me freely, is your System true? Hide nothing from me, I promise you secrecy. To me it seems grounded only on a little Conveniency superficial enough. A Star fixed and luminous in it self like the Sun, ought consequently to be as the Sun is, the Center and Soul of a World, and to have Planets turning about him. Is not this of absolute necessity?

P084: Hark you, Madam, said I, since 'tis our humour to mix the Folly of Gallantry with our most serious Discourse, the Reasonings of Mathematicks are like those of Love; grant but a Lover the least thing, and you are presently ingag'd to make a farther Concession, and then another, and so to the Worlds end. In like manner grant a Mathematician the least Principle, he'l deduce a Consequence that you must likewise grant, and from that another, and whether you will or not he'l carry you so far as you hardly believe. These two sort of people take more than is given them. You allow, that when two things are alike in what appears to me, I may believe they are also alike in what appears not to me, if nothing otherways hinders me. From hence I concluded that the Moon is inhabited, because she resembles the Earth, and that the Planets are, because they resemble Moon. I find that the fixed Stars resemble our Sun, and I attribute to them all that is in him. You are now too far ingag'd to retire, you must e'en go on. But, says she, according to this Resemblance you make between the fixed Stars and our Sun, it must needs be that the people of another great Vortex do not see him but as a little fixed Star, which appears to them only in their night.
