explanations: The French description of the inhabitants includes a second consequential clause ("& qui demeurent dans une nuit éternelle" - and who dwell in an eternal night). The English translation omits this second clause, simplifying the sentence by reducing its length and the density of information.

The French "N'y auroit-il pas moyen de me l'épargner?" (Wouldn't there be a way to spare me it?) uses a more formal and indirect interrogative construction. The English "can you no way excuse me that?" is more direct, uses simpler syntax, and arguably more common/colloquial vocabulary for the request.

The French "de fort habiles Gens" (very skilled/clever people) is simplified to "knowing men." "Knowing" is a more general and less nuanced adjective than "fort habiles" (very skilled/adept), using more common vocabulary.

The French "ne se remontrent pas" (do not show themselves again) is part of a longer complex temporal clause. The English simplifies this specific action to the more direct and concise phrase "and were never seen since," reducing the descriptive complexity of their non-reappearance.

The French phrase "tout s'y portera bien" (everything there will be/go well) is simplified to the very common, shorter English idiom "all's well," reducing text length and employing a more familiar expression.

The French "le gros des Tourbillons" (the bulk/mass/main part of the Vortices) is simplified to "the great Vortices." "Great" is a more general and common adjective, simplifying the vocabulary compared to conveying the specific meaning of "le gros de."

The specific French verb "se rallument" (re-ignite, re-light) is translated with the more periphrastic and arguably simpler phrase "take light again," using more common words instead of a single, less frequent verb like "re-ignite."

The French describes the crust with the additional detail "qui s'augmentera toûjours" (which will always keep growing). The English translation omits this characteristic ("qui s'augmentera toûjours"), simplifying the description of the crust.

The French "la rompit & la dissipa" (broke it and dissipated it) lists two distinct actions of the Sun's force. The English translation "it was dissipated" only conveys the second action ("dissipa"), omitting "rompit" (broke it), thus simplifying the event by reducing the number of described effects.

The French "si le Soleil ne l'est point luy même" (if the Sun itself is not [pale]) is simplified by the English pro-form "be so." This substitution makes the sentence more concise and employs a common English structure to avoid repeating the adjective "pale."
The French question "il ne faut que du temps?" (only time is needed? / does it only take time?) is simplified to the more direct, concise, and idiomatic English assertion "time will do it."

The French relative clause "dont aucune de ses parties n'est entierement exempte" (of which none of its parts is entirely exempt) is restructured into the simpler English coordinate clause "and no part of it wholly exempt," reducing grammatical complexity.

The French periphrastic expression "étoient de nature à ne changer jamais" (were of a nature never to change) is simplified to the single, more common adjective "unchangeable," making the phrasing more concise and direct.

The French "Avoient-ils eu le loisir de s'en assurer par l'expérience?" (Had they had the leisure to assure themselves of it by experience?) is simplified by replacing "le loisir" (leisure) with the more common "time enough," and the reflexive "s'en assurer" (assure themselves of it) with the more direct "to confirm their Opinion," using more straightforward vocabulary.

The somewhat abstract and impersonal French phrase "de memoire de Rose on n'a vû que luy" (in the memory of a rose, one has only seen him) is simplified to the more concrete and conventional narrative statement "our History tells us of no other."

The French "plus de fondement" (more foundation/basis) is simplified to "better ground," using a more common word. The clause "celuy que faisoient les Anciens" (that which the Ancients made/had) is simplified and made more explicit as "than the Ancients had for their Opinion," using a simpler verb structure.

The French "je ne les en croirois pas encore" (I would not believe them [about that] yet), which uses the complex pronominal adverb "en," is simplified to "yet I should not believe it," using the simpler pronoun "it" and a more direct construction.

The French idiomatic interrogative "Seroit-ce à dire que..." (Would that be to say that... / Does this mean that...) is simplified to the more direct question form "Can we argue that...". This makes the sentence structure less periphrastic and easier to follow.

The impersonal French construction "Il faudroit qu'une chose eût passé..." (It would be necessary that a thing had passed...) is simplified to the direct "A thing must have...". Furthermore, the descriptive phrase "passé bien des âges d'homme mis à bout" (passed many ages of man put end-to-end) is concisely rendered as "out-liv'd many Ages of Man," simplifying the structure by using a single effective verb.

The impersonal French passive construction "Il n'est pas à craindre qu'elle perisse" (It is not to be feared that it perishes) is simplified to the more direct, active, and common English phrasing "There is no fear of their perishing."
The French verb "se rapprochent [de nous]" (approach [us] again/come closer [to us]) is simplified to the more common and direct verb "return" in the context of stars reappearing.

The French modal perfect passive "peut avoir êté fait" (may have been made), expressing past possibility leading to a state, is simplified to the present state "is so made." This streamlines the verb phrase, making the sentence structure more direct.
The French adverbial phrase "à la longue" (in the long run, eventually) is simplified to the more common and concise "at last."

The French "la haute idée" (the high idea) is translated as "those great Ideas." In English, "great idea" is a more common and arguably simpler collocation than "high idea" for expressing a significant or grand concept.

The French "faire naître" (literally "to make born" or "to give birth to") is simplified in expression when applied to plants to "causing...to spring." "Spring" is a more common and direct verb for the emergence of plants. The shift from the conditional "N'auroit-elle" (Would she not have) to "Has not she" (Does she not have) also makes the question more direct.

The French "qu'il ne luy en coûte pas davantage" (that it does not cost her more for it) uses the pronominal adverb "en" (for it/of it). The English "and it costs her no more to do it" makes the referent explicit with "to do it," simplifying comprehension by resolving potential pronominal ambiguity.

The complex French idiom "être revenu de quelque chose" (to be disillusioned with/have changed one's mind about something after being disillusioned) is significantly simplified to "I have e'en left them." This translation conveys detachment but simplifies by omitting the specific nuance of disillusionment and the process of changing one's opinion.

The French "Revenons encore mieux" (Let's get over it/move on from this topic even more completely), which continues an idiomatic sense of disillusionment, is simplified to "Let us leave them more yet." "Leave them" is a simpler and more direct expression for ceasing discussion or mental engagement with the topic.
The French "voûte" (vault), a specific architectural term, is simplified to "Roof." "Roof" is a more common and general term, making the imagery more accessible and the vocabulary simpler.

The French "vôtre esprit" (your mind/spirit) is simplified to the more concrete "your thoughts." Additionally, the phrase "aussi loin que vont vos yeux" (as far as your eyes go) is rephrased to the more active and common English idiom "as far as you can reach with your eyes," simplifying the expression of visual limit.

chunks.sourceHtml: P105: Quoi, s'écria-t-elle, j'ay dans la tête tout le systeme de l'Univers! Je suis savante! Oüy, répliquay-je, vous l'êtes assez raisonnablement, & vous l'êtes avec la commodité de pouvoir ne rien croire de tout ce que je vous ay dit dés que l'envie vous en prendra. Je vous demande seulement pour recompense de mes peines de ne voir jamais le Soleil, ny le Ciel, ny les Etoiles, sans songer à moy.
chunks.manualHtml:
P113: So, says she, I have now the whole System of the Universe in my Head; I am now a knowing Woman.

P114: You are, said I, reasonable enough, and you are so with this conveniency, that you may believe nothing of all that I have said to you, till you please your self. I only request, as a Recompence for my pains, that you will never look upon the Sun, Heaven or Stars without thinking on me.
chunks.aiHtml:
P113: So, says she, I have now the whole System of the Universe in my Head; I am now a knowing Woman.

P114: You are, said I, reasonable enough, and you are so with this conveniency, that you may believe nothing of all that I have said to you, till you please your self. I only request, as a Recompence for my pains, that you will never look upon the Sun, Heaven or Stars without thinking on me.
explanations: The translation replaces the strong French exclamation 'Quoi, s'écria-t-elle!' (What! she exclaimed!) with 'So, says she,'. This reduces emotional intensity by substituting the emphatic 'Quoi!' with the milder 'So,' and the expressive verb 's'écria' (exclaimed/cried out) with the more general 'says.'

The term 'savante' (a learned/scholarly woman) is translated to 'a knowing Woman.' 'Knowing Woman' is a more common and potentially less formal term, simplifying the specific connotation of deep erudition present in 'savante'.

The French 'Oüy, répliquay-je' (Yes, I replied) becomes 'You are, said I'. The explicit 'Oüy' (Yes) is omitted (though affirmation is implied by 'You are'), and the specific verb 'répliquay-je' (replied) is simplified to the more common verb 'said'.

The French idiomatic phrase 'dés que l'envie vous en prendra' (literally 'as soon as the desire/whim takes you') is translated to the more general 'till you please your self.' This simplifies the original's nuanced implication of acting on a spontaneous whim into a more common and less evocative expression.
